    "content": "SOURCE / COMPANIES

E-commerce and challenges of air cargo amid decarbonization

Aviation shift in China

By Marco Leporati Published: Jan 15, 2026 10:34 PM 

Gianni di Giovanni, chairman of Eni China

According to a recent ranking of the world's 20 most important airports in terms of tonnage handled, eight are located in Asia, including four in China, with the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region and Shanghai at the top of the list. In addition to this snapshot, there are numerous Chinese hubs that are driving the growth of air transport for e-commerce. 

This premise is essential for analyzing outbound air transport from China to the rest of the world. While China and, more broadly, Asia leads the global air cargo market, assessing the current scenario is more challenging due to incomplete data for 2025, which presents a chiaroscuro effect stemming from China-US routes. 

The stop-and-go nature of tariffs has characterized moments of fluctuation depending on presidential executive orders and the resulting short-term decisions to seize opportunities for shipments with the benefit of reduced tariffs. 

In Europe, demand has weakened, influenced by certain decisions and actions taken by the European Union. Additionally, it is important to consider the Middle Eastern hubs that are creating a logistical bridge between China and Europe. 

Over this conventional cargo transport situation looms the cross-border traffic fueled by e-commerce. 

Taking the 42nd week of 2025 as a reference, the week following the early October holidays in Asia, global tonnage transported increased by an average of 6 percent, especially from Asian airports, which saw a 14 percent weekly increase and an 8 percent year-on-year increase. During the same period, air freight rates remained stable for flights toward Europe and increased by 2 percent for those heading to the US. 

Volatility was recently observed following negotiations between the US and China heads of state during the APEC meeting in South Korea. In the month before the Christmas holidays, there was no noticeable trend of overbooking, particularly when heading toward Europe. 

A worker loads cargo into an Air China plane.Photos: Courtesy of MF/Milano Finanza

Further confirmation of connectivity between China and Arab countries can be seen in two examples demonstrating the geopolitical shift and the attractiveness of the air segment of cross-border trade. 

Etihad Cargo, the division of the United Arab Emirates' Etihad Airways, signed a cooperative agreement in the summer of 2025 with a secondary but very active Chinese airport, Ezhou Huahu in Central China's Hubei Province, aimed at expanding cross-border operations, cold chain logistics, and the transport of high-value technological products. 

Another example is Chengdu Airport in Southwest China's Sichuan Province, which has taken the initiative to operate directly with a cargo plane to the Middle East. 

Qatar Airways Cargo and Cainiao, Alibaba's logistics company, have also entered into a collaborative agreement for more efficient distribution not only to the Middle East but also to Africa and Europe. 

If global growth for 2026, according to the International Monetary Fund's estimates, is projected at 3.1 percent, the maneuvering space in air transport will not be very wide, particularly for two factors. The first is the implementation of a charge, decided by the EU, of 2 euros ($2.33) on every package valued below 150 euros starting in January, aimed at mitigating the influx of fast fashion and ultra-fast fashion products. The opening of a Shein store in Paris, France, in the traditional temple of Galeries Lafayette, was an innovative event concerning European traditions and was well received by young consumers of the brand. 

In the US, the exemption for packages valued below $800 has already been eliminated, subjecting them to the corresponding tariffs. 

The second factor is the cost of jet fuel, particularly in relation to attempts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. Jet fuel accounts for 9 percent of all refined petroleum, but in Europe, oil companies avoid producing this derivative due to processing costs, resulting in a significant portion of the product being transferred daily from the Middle East, India, and Central Asia. 

Some, including Italy's largest oil company, Eni, are considering alternative solutions to jet fuel and are promoting research and experimentation of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), produced from non-fossil sources, such as used cooking oil (UCO). 

"A concrete example concerns the development of SAF supply chains based on local raw materials, particularly UCO, to support the decarbonization of aviation," explained Gianni di Giovanni, chairman of Eni in China, in a recent presentation in Beijing. "Both Europe and China consider SAF the main pathway in the medium term, thanks to the compatibility of existing infrastructure." According to the International Air Transport Association (IATA), the global airline association, SAF can contribute up to 65 percent of the total emissions reduction in the sector by 2050\. And China, a major air market and regional transport hub, has a unique competitive advantage in UCO feedstock. "It can be said that, for biofuels, China represents what Saudi Arabia represented for oil in the last century," concluded the manager. 

However, evident challenges remain: SAF costs are still 2-5 times higher than conventional jet fuel; there are no binding blending mandates or strong demand signals. Therefore, without a stable and predictable framework, utilization rates of facilities remain low. 

The EU has taken a step in the right direction by introducing Refuel EU Aviation with increasing mandates and significant support through EU ETS (approximately 1.5 billion euros in free allowances during the initial period); in the US, the SAF Grand Challenge and federal incentives are driving investments and demand. 

Decarbonization and consumption appear paradoxically to be an oxymoron, but in the near future, a reconciliation must be found. 

RELATED ARTICLES

 Wine producer bets on China

For decades, the Chinese wine scene has been a duopoly: on one side, the established elegance of French ...",

 Columbia County renewable diesel refinery faces another construction setback

By Alejandro Figueroa (OPB)

Jan. 16, 2026 2 p.m.

A massive renewable diesel refinery along the Columbia River needs to obtain yet another major federal permit before it can begin construction. 

In 2024, 1000 Friends of Oregon ‚Äì a land use policy watchdog ‚Äì and Hood River-based Columbia Riverkeeper filed a lawsuit in federal court claiming the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers ‚Äúillegally‚Äù greenlit construction for the planned refinery, allowing it to bypass a permit usually required when a company or local government intends to alter Army Corps civil works. 

THANKS TO OUR SPONSOR:

Become a Sponsor

The Army Corps is now walking back that greenlight.

FILE - The Columbia Pacific Bio-Refinery seen in the distance in the Port Westward Industrial Park, Clatskanie, Ore., May 30, 2025\. NEXT Renewable Fuels has also proposed a refinery at the industrial park

Alejandro Figueroa / OPB

NXTClean Fuels, also known as NEXT Renewable Fuels, is a Houston-based company proposing to build a $2.5 billion refinery outside Clatskanie at Port Westward, a small industrial park with deep-water access to the Columbia River.

When fully operational, the refinery would be able to crank out up to 50,000 barrels a day, or about 750 million gallons a year, of sustainable jet fuel and renewable diesel made with fish grease, animal tallow, used cooking oil and other oils from agricultural crops like soybeans and corn. 

Renewable diesel is chemically similar to petroleum-based fuels, which makes it compatible with traditional fossil fuel engines.

NEXT says the Oregon facility would generate $45 million per year in local and state tax revenue once in operation and create 3,500 construction jobs and 240 jobs during operation. Local elected officials and union groups have expressed support for the project.

Some local residents, farmers and environmental groups have long opposed the refinery, however, saying the facility could damage a system of dikes and levees that controls flooding in the area and that could disrupt nearby working farms. They‚Äôve also raised concerns that the facility could pollute the Columbia River. 

THANKS TO OUR SPONSOR:

Become a Sponsor

At issue with the most current federal lawsuit was a letter the Army Corps sent to NEXT in 2022\. In that letter, the Army Corps determined NEXT did not need a federal permit usually required when a developer intends to disrupt or alter Army Corps civil works projects ‚Äì in this case, the levees built by the Corps. 

During the construction of its refinery, NEXT plans to bring in heavy equipment and building materials via barge to a dock at Port Westward. It will then move those materials to the construction site using trucks. This requires those trucks to drive on a road that sits atop a levee, according to the complaint filed by Columbia Riverkeeper and 1000 Friends of Oregon. 

Audrey Leonard, a staff attorney at Columbia Riverkeeper, said those heavy trucks could damage the levee.

‚ÄúIt \[the levee\] really separates all of that area ‚Äì homes, energy infrastructure, and farmland ‚Äì from the Columbia River,‚Äù Leonard said. ‚ÄúAnd because it‚Äôs so old and because it sits underneath the road, it has degraded over time. It‚Äôs a real concern for people who live out there that rely on this levee.‚Äù

In August, a U.S. District judge filed a 23-page opinion, saying the nonprofits have a legal standing to proceed with their claims in federal court, and denying the Army Corps‚Äô motion to dismiss the case. 

Shortly after, the Army Corps filed a motion to stay the case, giving it time to go back and reconsider its earlier decision. 

Developers with NEXT describe the opposing environmental groups as ‚Äúanti-developmentist.‚Äù They say the court challenges are part of the group‚Äôs ‚Äústandard playbook‚Äù and that they‚Äôve worked to comply with federal and state regulations.

Now that the Army Corps has reversed its decision, NEXT will have to submit an application that the Corps will then have to review. The Corps will then decide whether construction will have any negative impacts on the levee.

Last summer, Columbia Riverkeeper filed a separate lawsuit claiming a water quality certification the Oregon Department of Environmental Quality issued to NEXT was ‚Äúlegally deficient.‚Äù That case is still pending. 

Developers with NEXT have told OPB they are close to breaking ground on the project, but they keep pushing the date. 

The refinery still needs to clear a few more permits, including an environmental impact assessment from the Army Corps. But that federal agency has pushed the release date of its own assessment at least twice. 

The Corps now expects to release a draft impact assessment in early 2026\. Then a public hearing will be scheduled.

Indonesia promotes bioavtur to cut aviation emissions 

Indonesia promotes bioavtur to cut aviation emissions 

January 19, 2026 20:51 GMT+700

Archives - President Director of PT Pertamina (Persero) Simon Aloysius Mantiri (second right) and Deputy President Director of PT Pertamina (Persero) Oki Muraza (second left) as well as President Director of Pertamina Patra Niaga Mars Ega Legowo Putra (right) directly observed the process of filling Bioavtur Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) into a Pelita Air aircraft during the Pertamina Sustainable Aviation Fuel Special Flight event at Terminal 3 of Soekarno Hatta Airport, Tangerang, Banten, Wednesday (8/20). Pertamina with various parties has successfully developed the Bioavtur Pertamina Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) product, which has been certified by ISCC CORSIA (International Sustainability and Carbon Certification: Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) and ISCC EU (International Sustainability and Carbon Certification: Renewable Energy Directive - European Union) so that it is eligible to sell sustainable products in accordance with CORSIA and RED (EU) provisions, where this product is Pertamina's commitment to reduce emissions in the Indonesian aviation world. ANTARA FOTO/Muhammad Iqbal/bar

 Jakarta (ANTARA) - Indonesia‚Äôs Ministry of Transportation is advancing the use of bioavtur‚Äîan aviation biofuel‚Äîas part of efforts to reduce carbon emissions in the national air transportation sector. 

Head of the Ministry‚Äôs Transportation Environmental Governance Division Dodhy Wiboso said the aviation industry plays a strategic role in achieving Indonesia‚Äôs emission reduction targets. 

‚ÄúBioavtur is part of our effort to achieve low-emission air transportation. This not only supports our commitment to reducing emissions but also ensures the long-term sustainability of the aviation sector,‚Äù Dodhy said here on Monday, adding that a gradual transition toward more environmentally friendly fuels is therefore essential. 

The ministry views bioavtur development and utilization as a key solution to reduce reliance on fossil-based jet fuel, while maintaining flight safety and operational standards. 

The initiative aligns with Indonesia‚Äôs national climate policies and commitment to a clean energy transition across the transportation sector, including civil aviation. 

Dodhy noted that successful implementation will require collaboration across ministries, industry stakeholders, and energy providers to ensure gradual and sustainable adoption. 

He pointed out that bioavtur is already in limited use, with Pelita Air operating flights using fuel processed from used cooking oil. 

However, production capacity remains insufficient, and palm oil‚Äîanother potential feedstock‚Äîcontinues to face sustainability concerns. 

‚ÄúIn the future, if palm oil is to be used for bioavtur, we must be able to prove that the raw material is sustainable,‚Äù Dodhy stressed. 

The ministry reaffirmed its commitment to promoting innovation and strengthening environmental governance in aviation, aiming to build a more sustainable national transportation system.

 Oleochemicals Production Plant DPR - 2026, Cost Structure, Machinery, and Profit Analysis

 Oleochemicals production involves converting natural oils and fats into bio-based chemicals like fatty acids and glycerin, widely used across sustainable industrial applications.

Published 20 January 2026

Oleochemicals production is emerging as a critical industry driven by growing demand for bio-based chemicals, sustainability initiatives, and the global shift away from petrochemicals. With strong demand from personal care, detergents, food processing, pharmaceuticals, and industrial applications, oleochemicals production offers attractive opportunities for entrepreneurs and investors seeking sustainable and profitable business models.

Understanding the oleochemicals production plant setup cost is essential for entrepreneurs and investors looking to capitalize on this environmentally conscious and economically viable industrial sector. This comprehensive guide covers every investment aspect from raw material sourcing to finished oleochemical products, helping you make informed decisions about entering the oleochemicals manufacturing business.

What is Oleochemicals Production and Market Opportunity

Oleochemicals production involves processing natural fats and oils from vegetable, animal, and marine sources to produce fatty acids, fatty alcohols, glycerin, and their derivatives. Modern oleochemicals manufacturing encompasses diverse feedstocks from palm oil and coconut oil to tallow and fish oils, serving as sustainable alternatives to petroleum-based chemicals. The industry combines environmental responsibility with economic value creation, producing biodegradable and renewable chemicals for numerous industrial and consumer applications.

Primary Products and Applications:

Fatty acids for soap, detergents, and personal care products
Fatty alcohols for surfactants and cosmetic formulations
Glycerin for pharmaceuticals, food, and industrial applications
Methyl esters for biodiesel and solvents
Fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) for various industrial uses
Soap noodles and toilet soap manufacturing
Esters for lubricants and plasticizers
Glycerides for food emulsifiers and confectionery
Amines and amides for fabric softeners and corrosion inhibitors
Alkanolamides for detergent formulations
Polymer additives and processing aids
Industrial lubricants and metalworking fluids

With increasing consumer preference for natural products, stringent environmental regulations, growing awareness of sustainability, and government incentives for bio-based chemical production, oleochemicals demand continues its strong upward trajectory across both developed and emerging markets worldwide.

Complete Breakdown of Oleochemicals Production Plant Setup Costs

1\. Land Acquisition and Infrastructure Development

Strategic location balancing raw material access and market proximity is critical for operations:

Land purchase or long-term lease in industrial zones with adequate space
Site preparation, leveling, and foundation work for heavy processing equipment
Boundary development with secure perimeter fencing
Internal roads capable of handling tanker trucks and heavy vehicles
Large receiving areas for bulk liquid and solid feedstocks
Utility infrastructure connections including steam, power, and water
Tank farm foundations with proper containment systems
Employee facilities, parking, and administrative buildings
Environmental compliance infrastructure including effluent treatment systems
Security systems with fire detection and safety equipment

Location Strategy: Proximity to ports or oil mills for feedstock access, connectivity to major consumer markets, availability of industrial utilities including steam and power, and skilled workforce availability ensures optimal supply chain economics while minimizing logistics costs.

Request for a Sample Report: 

2\. Raw Material Storage and Handling Infrastructure

Bulk material management and inventory systems required:

Large storage tanks for liquid oils and fats with heating systems
Insulated tanks for temperature-sensitive materials
Separate storage for different feedstock grades and types
Tank farm with proper containment bunds and drainage
Solid fat storage facilities with melting equipment
Chemical storage tanks for process additives and catalysts
Glycerin and finished product storage with quality preservation
Loading and unloading facilities for tanker trucks and rail cars
Pumping systems and transfer pipelines throughout facility
Nitrogen blanketing systems for oxidation-sensitive materials
Inventory management and quality tracking systems
Fire suppression systems for storage areas

3\. Processing Equipment and Machinery

Core production technology represents the major capital investment component:

Primary Processing Equipment:

Fat splitting systems (high-pressure or enzymatic)
Distillation columns for fatty acid purification
Fractionation equipment for fatty acid separation
Hydrogenation reactors for saturated fatty acid production
Methyl esterification reactors for FAME production
Glycerin refining and purification systems
Soap splitting equipment for crude fatty acid recovery
Continuous splitting plants for high-volume operations

Fatty Alcohol Production:

Hydrogenation reactors for fatty alcohol synthesis
High-pressure reaction vessels and autoclave systems
Distillation units for alcohol purification
Fractionation columns for different chain length separation
Catalyst handling and recovery systems
Product finishing and blending equipment

Downstream Processing:

Esterification reactors for specialty ester production
Sulfonation units for surfactant manufacturing
Ethoxylation reactors for non-ionic surfactant production
Amination equipment for fatty amine derivatives
Neutralization and washing systems
Bleaching and deodorization equipment
Winterization systems for product clarity

Utilities Generation:

High-pressure steam boilers for process heat
Thermal fluid heating systems for temperature control
Vacuum systems for distillation operations
Cooling towers and chilled water systems
Compressed air generation and distribution
Hot water circulation systems

Quality Control Equipment:

Gas chromatography for composition analysis
Titration equipment for acid value determination
Moisture analyzers and testing instruments
Color measurement spectrophotometers
Viscosity and density measuring equipment
Laboratory setup for comprehensive quality testing

4\. Environmental Control Systems

Compliance infrastructure essential for regulatory approval and sustainable operations:

Effluent treatment plant for process wastewater recycling
Biological treatment systems for organic load reduction
Oil-water separation and recovery systems
Air pollution control for odor and VOC emissions
Scrubbers and absorption towers for process emissions
Condensate recovery and treatment systems
Solid waste handling and disposal infrastructure
Stack emissions monitoring equipment
Environmental parameter monitoring and reporting systems
Spill containment and emergency response equipment

5\. Utilities and Energy Systems

Essential supporting infrastructure for continuous operation requirements:

High-capacity electrical power supply with adequate transformer capacity
Dedicated substation for heavy power requirements
Backup generators for critical operations during outages
Steam generation systems (coal, gas, or biomass-fired boilers)
Fuel storage and handling systems for boiler operations
Demineralized water plant for boiler feed and process water
Cooling water systems with recirculation and treatment
Compressed air generation with moisture removal
Nitrogen generation plant for blanketing and inerting
Fire detection, alarm, and suppression systems throughout facility
Emergency lighting and safety evacuation infrastructure

6\. Civil Works and Buildings

Physical infrastructure requirements encompassing entire facility:

Main process building with adequate height for column installation
Reactor halls with proper ventilation and safety systems
Distillation area with structural support for tall columns
Packaging and filling hall for finished products
Warehouse for packed goods with temperature control
Boiler house and utility generation building
Maintenance workshop and spare parts storage
Quality control laboratory with proper ventilation
Administrative offices and control room
Employee facilities including changing rooms and cafeteria
Security office and main gate infrastructure
Chemical storage building with safety compliance
Tank farm area with proper containment and drainage

7\. Material Handling and Logistics

Efficient movement infrastructure throughout operations:

Pumping systems for liquid material transfer
Pipeline network with proper valving and instrumentation
Transfer pumps for different viscosity materials
Metering systems for accurate material measurement
Automated filling and packaging lines
Conveyor systems for packaged goods movement
Forklifts and material handling vehicles
Tank truck loading facilities with metering
Drum and container filling stations
Weighbridges for incoming and outgoing materials

8\. Instrumentation and Control Systems

Manufacturing management and monitoring infrastructure for operational excellence:

Distributed Control System (DCS) for process automation
Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) for equipment control
Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems
Temperature, pressure, and flow measurement instrumentation
Analytical instruments for online quality monitoring
Safety instrumented systems for emergency shutdown
Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) for business management
Manufacturing Execution System (MES) for production tracking
Inventory management with automated reporting
Customer relationship management (CRM) platform
Financial accounting and cost management software

9\. Engineering and Pre-operative Costs

Project development and regulatory compliance expenses before operations commence:

Comprehensive feasibility study and market analysis
Process design and engineering consultancy
Detailed engineering and plant layout development
Environmental impact assessment and clearances
Pollution control board approvals and consent
Industrial licenses and regulatory authorizations
Food safety certifications if applicable (FSSAI, FDA)
Technology licensing fees if using proprietary processes
Equipment procurement, installation, and commissioning
Trial runs and process optimization
Staff recruitment, training, and skill development programs
Initial raw material procurement and inventory buildup
Marketing collateral and customer development initiatives
Supplier qualification and approval processes

10\. Working Capital Requirements

Initial operational funds for smooth business continuity:

Raw material procurement (vegetable oils, fats, chemicals)
Utilities including steam, power, and water consumption
Employee salaries, wages, and benefits
Catalyst and chemical consumables
Packaging materials for finished products
Marketing and business development expenses
Transportation and logistics for raw materials and products
Customer credit periods for product sales
Equipment maintenance and spare parts inventory
Quality testing and certification costs
Administrative and overhead expenses
Contingency reserves for feedstock price fluctuations

By Choi Youn-jin
Published Jan 20, 2026 4:19 pm KST

Greenda‚Äôs bio-aviation fuel production plant in Jeungpyeong County, North Chungcheong Province / Courtesy of Greenda

Andreessen Horowitz, also known as a16z, is the world‚Äôs largest venture capital firm, managing assets worth about $63 billion as of last year. Co-founded by Marc Andreessen, creator of the Netscape web browser, and Ben Horowitz, the firm is famous for making early bets on startups that have since become superstars, including OpenAI, Meta, Airbnb and Roblox.

While many venture capital firms were fixated on artificial intelligence (AI) in 2024, a16z shifted its gaze elsewhere, promoting a thesis it calls "American Dynamism." The concept refers to investing in sectors that strengthen the national interest and competitiveness of the United States, such as defense, energy, manufacturing and space.

The firm‚Äôs emphasis on American dynamism stems from the realization that global supply chains fractured during the COVID-19 pandemic. In response, a16z saw the need to restructure supply networks around the U.S., in alignment with the "America First" doctrine loudly advocated by President Donald Trump. In essence, American dynamism means breaking away from an AI-only focus and diversifying startup investments into sectors that boost national competitiveness and economic vitality.

Choi Youn-jin 

A similar trend is now emerging among startup accelerators and venture capital firms in Korea. Moving away from the AI bandwagon, they are turning to sectors like energy and the defense industry. Borrowing the term, this shift could be called "Korean dynamism" ‚Äî a push for fields that ensure long-term national competitiveness in the global market.

One example is Bluepoint, a Korean startup accelerator that has recently concentrated investments in energy technologies supporting AI, quantum computing and small modular reactors, where global dominance is still unclear, as well as in defense, which is vital for domestic industrial growth.

Among its portfolio companies is Greenda, which collects waste cooking oil to produce sustainable aviation fuel. In other words, it turns discarded cooking oil into fuel that can power aircraft. While it may sound implausible at first glance, the bio-aviation fuel Greenda produces is already being exported and used as aircraft fuel abroad. As the climate crisis deepens, the alternative energy sector promises long-term growth.

Another Korean startup, Newtype Industries, develops defense software that uses AI to guide tactical shooting based on commanders‚Äô combat experience. The software drew significant attention by demonstrating 100 percent accuracy during a U.S. Army demonstration. Bluepoint also invested in this company.

For Korea‚Äôs startup sector, proactive efforts are essential to uncover hidden fields strengthening long-term national competitiveness. This is the path to securing future technological sovereignty and enhancing the nation‚Äôs resilience and autonomy.

The writer heads the Startuplab section of the Hankook Ilbo, where he covers the IT and startup sectors. This column from the Hankook Ilbo, the sister publication of The Korea Times, is translated by a generative AI system and edited by The Korea Times.",

Mahoney Environmental Achieves Dual ISCC Certifications, Expanding Feedstock Options for Clean Fuels

Used cooking oil recycler becomes certified for both EU and international aviation sustainability programs, strengthening the supply chain for clean fuels.

WOODRIDGE, Ill., Jan. 19, 2026 /PRNewswire/ -- Mahoney Environmental Solutions, LLC achieved International Sustainability and Carbon Certification (ISCC) for both EU and CORSIA (Carbon Offsetting Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) programs. With over 70 years of experience, Mahoney is now positioned by this dual certification to supply verified feedstocks to manufacturers of renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel. 

The certifications enable Mahoney to formally verify that its collected used cooking oil qualifies as genuine waste and residue under international sustainability standards. Also, it is crucial for fuel manufacturers who need certified feedstock to produce renewable fuels and biofuels that meet EU renewable energy requirements and international aviation carbon offset standards. 

"The ISCC Certification opens doors to new markets and creates competitive advantages by showing compliance with increasingly stringent sustainability regulations. Also, it provides third-party verification of responsible sourcing practices, builds trust with buyers, and positions Mahoney as a reliable partner in sustainable supply chains." ? Dave Kimball, CEO and President

Expanding the Sustainable Fuel Supply Chain 

As a subsidiary of Neste, the world's leading producer of sustainable aviation fuel and renewable diesel, Mahoney plays a role in securing feedstock for clean fuel production. Additionally, the ISCC certifications help address the growing demand for verified sustainable materials as airlines work to meet carbon reduction commitments and governments implement renewable fuel standards. 

"For feedstock providers, like Mahoney, the ISCC certification transforms our feedstock into a verified sustainable commodity that commands better prices and secures long-term contracts with environmentally conscious manufacturers," said Brian Murphy, Finished Product Sales Manager. 

About Mahoney Environmental 

Founded in 1953, Mahoney Environmental helps food service companies transform used cooking oil and other waste products. They manage the entire recycling process from equipment installation and waste collection to processing and finished product delivery, enabling nearly 100% material recovery at all facilities. 

Mahoney serves food service operators nationwide, from major restaurant chains to independent establishments and airport concessions. In 2020, Neste (HEL: NESTE) acquired Mahoney Environmental, strengthening the global supply chain for sustainable aviation fuel and renewable diesel production. 

Finally, Mahoney is a licensed EPA and ISCC Certified recycler committed to being the premier back-of-house service provider for the food service industry. While striving to create a safer planet for future generations.

Motorists lost ¬£3.6m in unused Dart Charge payments in two years - as government pockets most of the cash

Read all comments | 

Sean McPolin 

smcpolin@thekmgroup.co.uk

Published: 11:45, 13 January 2026 

|
 | 
 |
 | 

Drivers have lost more than ¬£3.6million in unused Dart Charge payments over the past two years ‚Äî with the Government pocketing most of the cash.

New figures show motorists failed to reclaim ¬£1,812,379 in expired payments for using the Dartford Crossing during the 2023/24 financial year, on top of ¬£1,790,559 the year before.

The Dartford Crossing carries up to 180,000 cars a day. Image: Department for Transport

Prepaid credits lapse after 12 months and, unless motorists claim a refund in time are fed back into Department for Transport (DfT) coffers.

The revelations follows a freedom of information request sent to National Highways - the department responsible for managing the crossing's payment system ‚Äî which revealed the mouthwatering sums wasted by drivers over a 24-month period.

It brings the total amount lost by drivers now to ¬£3,602,938 in just two years, This is Money reports.

Motorists are charged ¬£3.50 each way to use the Dartford Crossing between Kent and Essex, with payments remaining valid for 12 months before expiring.

Drivers can request a refund within that period, while dormant Dart Charge accounts are automatically refunded using the original payment method. However, any charges not reclaimed in time are effectively lost.

Motorists have reported problems trying to pay the DartCharge previously

The Dartford Crossing is one of the busiest river crossings in the country, carrying up to 180,000 vehicles a day, many of them travelling to and from Kent.

A National Highways spokesman told KentOnline all the money raised by the Dart Charge is passed onto government and ring-fenced for investment in transport projects that benefit people locally, such as the Lower Thames Crossing.

But President of the Automobiles Association (AA) Edmund King criticised the situation. He told the Mirror: ‚ÄúThe real irony is the Dartford crossing original agreement was that the tolls would stop once the bridge's construction costs were paid off, a milestone reached in 2003.

‚ÄúHowever, the government reversed its decision, retaining the charges to manage traffic and as a general revenue raiser.‚Äù

Tolls were allowed to continue after the Transport Act 2000, which introduced charging schemes for trunk roads, bridges and tunnels longer than 600 metres.

The Dart Charge was increased in 2014, before rising again in September 2025, as the government presses ahead with plans for the Lower Thames Crossing.

The long-delayed project would link the A2 and M2 in Kent with the A13 and M25 in Essex via a 2.6-mile tunnel beneath the Thames, making it the longest road tunnel in the UK.

It‚Äôs been in the works since 2009, with more than ¬£800million of taxpayers‚Äô money already spent on planning alone and an extra ¬£891m allocated in the most recent government budget.

Construction enabling works on a major project are well underway with an anticipated finish date in the early 2030s.

Dartford Gravesham Kent Politics Transport Sean McPolin

 University of Iowa, Iowa State bus systems land grants supporting eco-friendly upgrades

UI Cambus to replace six aging buses with diesel-electric hybrid versions

Vanessa Miller 

Jan. 19, 2026 4:03 pm, Updated: Jan. 20, 2026 7:31 am

 Why you can trust The Gazette 

 A Cambus drives around the University of Iowa campus in Iowa City on Monday. (Savannah Blake/The Gazette)

 Buy Photo 

The Gazette offers audio versions of articles using Instaread. Some words may be mispronounced.

IOWA CITY ‚Äî Transit systems across Iowa recently landed $77.2 million in Federal Transit Administration grant funding, including $20.8 million to make the University of Iowa and Iowa State University bus systems more environmentally-friendly.

CyRide ‚Äî celebrating its 50th year serving Iowa State ‚Äî received $14.6 million to expand its facility and convert 20 buses to biodiesel; Cambus ‚Äî shuttling UI students for 54 years ‚Äî got $6.2 million to replace six 17- and 18-year-old buses with diesel-electric hybrid versions.

Beyond the environmental benefits, UI transportation officials said the replacement project will improve service and the rider experience.

‚ÄúNewer buses require less maintenance and are less likely to cause service disruptions due to breakdowns,‚Äù UI Cambus officials said in reporting the award. ‚ÄúThey will also offer a more comfortable riding experience for the university community.‚Äù

Iowa State‚Äôs nearly $15 million award supports its major expansion of CyRide‚Äôs administrative, maintenance and bus storage facility that will:

Provide indoor storage space for the entire nearly 90-bus fleet;
Add maintenance capacity to serve clean-fuel vehicles;
Expand training space to support a growing 200-plus workforce;
Enhance operational capacity in expectation of continued long-term expansion;
And convert 20 buses to operate on 100-percent biodiesel ‚Äî including installation of an underground B100 fuel tank and on-site blending equipment.

CyRide already has five B100 buses as part of a pilot program launched last year, and officials report promising results ‚Äî including reduced emissions.

‚ÄúB100 continues to perform well in our pilot, and this funding allows us to build on that success across more of our fleet,‚Äù CyRide Transit Director Barbara Neal said in a statement ‚Äî referencing the larger facility-expansion initiative.

‚ÄúThis project will give our employees the space and resources needed to support our transit system, and it allows us to expand our use of B100 ‚Äî a clean, Iowa-grown fuel that benefits the environment and strengthens our state‚Äôs agricultural economy.‚Äù

Cambus expansion

The University of Iowa also is in the midst of a $23 million expansion of its Cambus Maintenance Facility ‚Äî thanks to a separate $16.4 million federal grant to increase bus storage, accommodate electric buses and chargers, and centralize administrative, driver and maintenance staff.

The new facility will house not just Cambus but all of Fleet Services ‚Äî which maintains the entire UI vehicle fleet, including more than 500 university vehicles that can be rented for official university business.

Its recently awarded grant supporting replacement of six buses ‚Äî through the FTA‚Äôs ‚ÄúLow and No Emissions Program‚Äù ‚Äî supports the larger reimagining of UI transit services.

 A Cambus drives past the University of Iowa campus after making a stop in Iowa City on Monday. (Savannah Blake/The Gazette)

 Buy Photo 

‚ÄúOur goal is to provide safe and accessible transportation services to everyone on campus,‚Äù Cambus Manager Mia Brunelli said. ‚ÄúInvestments like these to improve our fleet and infrastructure are vital to achieving that goal.‚Äù

The new buses will replace six buses bought in 2008 and 2009 that were supposed to be retired nearly four years ago in 2022.

‚ÄúBecause the maintenance costs for older buses are 60 to 70 percent higher, replacing them will also significantly lower costs,‚Äù officials said.

 By the numbers

Cambus provides more than 12,000 daily rides to the UI community ‚Äî including to and from class, work, home, events and recreation facilities. Annually, that amounts to more than 3 million rides a year on 13 fixed routes ‚Äî or 80,000 annual hours of service.

Conceived and started by UI students in 1972 to improve access between the east and west sides of campus, Cambus continues to be operated and supervised by students ‚Äî with 160 student employees.

Iowa State‚Äôs CyRide ‚Äî from its genesis in 1976 when it was a ‚ÄúDial-A-Ride door-to-door system‚Äù ‚Äî in the 2025 budget year tallied nearly 5 million passengers and 1.5 million ‚Äúrevenue miles.‚Äù

The system has 89 buses and 214 employees ‚Äî requiring $15 million in operating expenses last year.

Other FTA grants to Iowa in 2025 included $8.7 million to the City of Iowa City for diesel and paratransit buses to replace older models; $27.8 million to the Iowa Department of Transportation for new buses and vans; and another $19.9 million to the DOT for hybrid buses and bus facility expansions on behalf of four rural transit systems.

Vanessa Miller covers higher education for The Gazette.

Planning & Construction News

 World‚Äôs largest luffing crane begins work in Walsall

January 19, 2026 

479

Image: ¬©Marr Contracting

Marr‚Äôs M2480D crane, the highest capacity tower crane in the world, has been deployed to work on the Walsall Energy Recovery Facility (ERF)

Marr Contracting have been awarded the contract to deploy the world‚Äôs largest luffing crane to Walsall in the West Midlands.

The ERF facility the crane is working on is being delivered by Encyclis, and will convert 436,000 tonnes of non-recyclable waste into 49Mwe of energy.

 The M2480D provides a single-crane solution

Using its capacity of 100 tonnes, the luffing crane will help in the installation of the 78-tonne economiser and the 69-tonne boiler drum. The crane is built in an area where it will not need to be moved when lifting these separate objects.

This also reduces the number of lifts needed, supporting the Design for Manufacture and Assembly approach, maximising productivity and safety.

Steve Ryder, Marr Contracting‚Äôs general manager ‚Äì international, said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre proud to be supporting Kanadevia Inova on the Walsall ERF, where our heavy lifting solution demonstrates how smart crane engineering can make a real difference on complex construction projects.‚Äù

Managing director Simon Marr said: ‚ÄúDrawing on our experience delivering similar large-scale energy-from-waste and industrial projects in the UK, Australia and Middle East, we‚Äôre delivering a safer, more efficient lifting approach, which has been tailored to meet the project‚Äôs specific needs.‚Äù

More giant cranes are coming to the UK

Earlier this month, Mammoet purchased two giant crawler cranes, a Liebherr LR11350 and LR12500-1.0.

The latter specifically is one of the largest crawler cranes made by Liebherr, with only the LR13000 being bigger. Mammoet already owns one of these cranes, with a capacity for 3,000t.

The LR11350 boasts a maximum load capacity of 1,350t with a hoist of 220m, while the LR12500-1.0 can lift up to 2,500t.

Peter van Oostrom, Global Projects and Assets director at Mammoet, said: ‚ÄúTo ensure we continue to have a crane fleet best fitting market requirements and most modern fleet of cranes in the world, it is important that we invest in new machines from leading manufacturers.

‚ÄúLiebherr is a worldwide supplier and the logical choice for cranes of this capacity.

‚ÄúWe therefore see it being in very high demand, particularly for offshore wind projects‚Äù.

Christoph Kleiner, managing director at Liebherr said: ‚ÄúMammoet has been a key partner to Liebherr for many years, providing valuable input into the development of new crane hardware. Its insight into usability and future capacity requirements is invaluable.

‚ÄúWe have a strong relationship with Mammoet and are delighted it has added two more Liebherr cranes to its world-class fleet‚Äù.

Primafrio Marks Milestone with Fifth Consecutive Flota Ecol√≥gica Certification from AEGFA

 by James Miller 

6 minutes read 

News 

January 19, 2026 

 Leading the Charge Toward Greener Logistics

Primafrio, a well-known international logistics operator specializing in Europe‚Äôs temperature-controlled transportation of fresh produce, has once again demonstrated its commitment to environmental responsibility by renewing the Flota Ecol√≥gica certification for the fifth consecutive year. This recognition isn‚Äôt just a trophy on the shelf‚Äîit‚Äôs a testament to the company‚Äôs consistent investments in eco-innovation and energy efficiency, setting a benchmark for the industry.

What is the Flota Ecol√≥gica Certification?

The Flota Ecol√≥gica certification, developed over a decade ago by AEGFA (Asociaci√≥n Espa√±ola de Gestores de Flotas de Autom√≥viles) in collaboration with IDAE (Instituto para la Diversificaci√≥n y Ahorro de la Energ√≠a), is a coveted accolade awarded to fleets committed to sustainable mobility. It involves rigorous annual assessments to ensure ongoing compliance with environmental goals and the continuous adoption of new initiatives aimed at cutting down emissions and optimizing fleet operations.

 AEGFA and Primafrio‚Äôs Collaboration

Primafrio joined the AEGFA improvement program back in 2021 and has met all the prescribed goals since. This impressive track record highlights the company‚Äôs strategic direction in embedded sustainability within its core logistics operations.

Innovation and Consistency: The Pillars Behind the Certification

What‚Äôs particularly eye-catching is Primafrio‚Äôs fleet composition, boasting an exceptionally young average vehicle age of just 1.2 years. This ensures not only a reduction in fuel consumption but also a decrease in CO‚ÇÇ emissions, reflecting a smart mix of constant renewal and modern technology adoption. In 2025, the company accelerated its push towards sustainable transport, which is further validated by a series of prestigious environmental certifications including the Lean & Green 4th Star, ISO 14064, and ISO 50001.

| Key Sustainability Initiatives at Primafrio | Description |
| ------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Fleet Renewal | Maintaining a young average vehicle age of 1.2 years to enhance fuel efficiency and reduce emissions. |
| Electric Trucks | In 2022, introduced 15 fully electric 40-ton trucks for long-distance hauls ‚Äî a national first in Spain. |
| Renewable Energy Infrastructure | Constructed Spain‚Äôs most powerful electric truck charging station powered by solar plants at headquarters. |
| Alternative Fuel Adoption | Utilizes renewable liquid fuels such as HVO (hydrogenated vegetable oil) and B100 biodiesel. |
| Hydrogen Fuel Technology | Invests in hydrogen fuel cells and compatible combustion engines to meet long-term carbon neutrality goals. |
| Driver Training Programs | Implements driving efficiency programs reducing fuel consumption and emissions by up to 40%. |
| Carbon Footprint Verification | Monitors and verifies carbon emissions with internationally recognized GHG Protocol standards. |

 A Technological Leap: Electric Trucks and Self-Generated Power

One of the standout achievements is the integration of 15 electric trucks that Primafrio introduced as part of its green fleet. These vehicles operate on a pioneering charging station capable of simultaneously servicing 16 heavy trucks, fueled exclusively by solar power generated through the company‚Äôs own photovoltaic plants. This multi-megawatt setup (up to 2.4 MWp) represents a game changer in freight haulage electrification, reducing reliance on grid electricity and thus minimizing the environmental footprint.

Training Drivers for Efficiency and Safety

Primafrio doesn‚Äôt leave sustainability to technology alone; it actively invests in driver education. Their innovative Program of Efficient Driving has trained over 3,000 drivers who have collectively cut fuel consumption and CO‚ÇÇ emissions by nearly 3,700 tonnes, thanks to techniques like preventive driving and virtual simulators. This hands-on approach enhances safety, reduces wear-and-tear, and optimizes fuel usage‚Äîan all-around win for logistics efficiency.

 Digital Security and Environmental Accountability

The company also bolsters its robust logistics strategy with a fortified cybersecurity center, ensuring digital operations run smoothly and securely, which is vital in the era of connected logistics networks.

In addition, Primafrio rigorously verifies its carbon footprint following the strict Greenhouse Gas Protocol globally recognized standard for transparency and precision, fortifying its leadership in sustainable logistics operations.

The Multienergy Approach: Looking Beyond Traditional Fuels

Primafrio is betting on a diversified energy future, embracing a multitechnological strategy. Besides electric traction, the company explores hydrogen fuel cells and bio-compatible internal combustion engines using renewable gases. Concurrently, it uses liquid biofuels like HVO and B100 that have lower emissions, ensuring its fleet is prepared for a greener tomorrow.

 Summary of Sustainable Practices

Renewable energy use: Photovoltaic plants to self-generate charging power for electric trucks
Fleet electrification: Deployment of 40-ton fully electric trucks on long-haul routes
Advanced fuels: Use of biofuels and emerging hydrogen technologies
Driver efficiency: Training programs achieving significant emission reductions
Certification and reporting: Compliance with international protocols and environmental standards

Why This Matters for the Logistics Industry

In the fast-evolving world of logistics and freight transport, sustainability is no longer just a buzzword but a necessity. Primafrio‚Äôs achievements highlight how integrating environmental stewardship can go hand-in-hand with operational excellence. For the logistics sector, adopting similar strategies means cutting costs through fuel efficiency, reducing carbon taxes and penalties, and improving brand reputation among increasingly eco-conscious customers. Moreover, the push towards electric and hydrogen fleets impacts cargo delivery dynamics, requiring infrastructure adaptations such as advanced charging stations or renewable energy sources‚Äîa challenge and opportunity for the whole industry.

 The Human Factor in Sustainable Transport

Even the best technologies and certifications can only take operations so far. The true game changer is in empowering the workforce through training and awareness. Primafrio‚Äôs investment in driver education exemplifies how a skilled, conscientious team can play a pivotal role in reducing energy use and improving safety while ensuring smooth freight movements.

Experience Trumps Words: Making Informed Transport Choices

While certifications and awards speak volumes, nothing quite beats firsthand experience when choosing a logistics partner or method. Fortunately, platforms like GetTransport.com make it easy to find reliable and eco-conscious cargo transport solutions worldwide‚Äîfrom office and home moves to bulky freight and vehicle transport. This gives shippers the power to weigh options, compare transparent pricing, and secure efficient delivery services that meet their specific needs without breaking the bank.

GetTransport.com‚Äôs global reach, affordability, and versatile service offerings make it a go-to platform for anyone involved in freight, shipping, or relocation. Choosing such a platform allows smooth navigation of the logistics maze while embracing greener transport options. Book your Ride with GetTransport.com.

 Looking Ahead: The Impact on Global Logistics

Although these developments from Primafrio might seem focused on regional logistics, they mirror a broader shift in the industry worldwide toward eco-friendly practices. While the immediate global impact might be modest, the company‚Äôs pioneering role sets an example that resonates internationally, pushing the freight and shipping sectors toward a more sustainable future.

GetTransport.com keeps pace with these trends, ensuring that customers benefit from innovations and sustainability in logistics. Start planning your next delivery and secure your cargo with GetTransport.com.

Wrapping It Up

In sum, Primafrio‚Äôs fifth renewal of the Flota Ecol√≥gica certification is more than just a seal of approval. It‚Äôs a narrative of consistent dedication to greener logistics through fleet renewal, multienergy use, driver training, and renewable infrastructure. This reflects a logistics future where environmental responsibility and freight efficiency walk hand in hand. For anyone navigating the complicated waters of international or domestic shipping, platforms like GetTransport.com offer a reliable, transparent, and cost-effective path forward, whether it‚Äôs parcels, pallets, bulky goods, or entire relocations. Embracing sustainable logistics has never been so accessible and practical.

Biofuels boom lifts agroindustry investments to R$60bn

 Corn ethanol surge drove record infrastructure and industrial plans in 2025, a Valor survey shows

 Por 

Camila Souza Ramos 

, 

Nayara Figueiredo 

 e 

Cibelle Bou√ßas 

‚Äî S√£o Paulo and Belo Horizonte 

 19/01/2026 06h11 Atualizado h√° 3 dias 

---

/i.s3.glbimg.com/v1/AUTH37554604729d4b2f9f3eb9ad8a691345/internalphotos/bs/2026/L/u/wb6ajBSaeY9fq3s5JDDQ/foto19agr-101-investe-b8.jpg) 

 Inpasa‚Äôs corn ethanol plant in Dourados, Mato Grosso do Sul ‚Äî Foto: Wenderson Ara√∫jo/CNA 

 Agribusiness and infrastructure projects announced in Brazil for 2025 totaled more than R$60 billion, according to an exclusive survey by Valor based on data from consulting firms, industry associations, and press releases. A wave of new corn ethanol plants accounted for a significant share of that figure. 

 Last year alone, investments announced in corn ethanol production capacity reached R$41 billion, according to a study by consultancy FG/A conducted for Valor. 

 These funds will be allocated to 44 projects that, if completed, will add 12 billion liters per year to Brazil‚Äôs ethanol production capacity. The largest investment was announced at the end of 2025 by Inpasa: R$3.5 billion for a new plant in Rondon√≥polis, in the state of Mato Grosso, and the expansion of its Nova Mutum facility, also in Mato Grosso. 

Robust harvest puts pressure on Brazilian grain storage
Agriculture drives doubling of Brazil‚Äôs biomethane capacity

 The total investment pledged for corn ethanol in 2025 surpasses the R$30 billion invested in sugarcane ethanol projects between 2009 and 2012, according to a 2009 survey by Valor. 

 Willian Hernandes, partner at FG/A, said the corn ethanol boom is driven by the segment‚Äôs attractive profit margins and favorable financing conditions. 

 With Brazil‚Äôs abundant corn supply, the cost of producing ethanol from the grain has become more competitive than sugarcane-based ethanol, allowing the product to reach new markets. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an opportunity to sell a higher value-added product \[than corn\], and the infrastructure is already in place,‚Äù said Felippe Serigatti, a professor at FGV Agro. 

 To navigate high interest rates, many of the announced investments were financed through the Brazilian Development Bank (BNDES) Climate Fund, which offers loans at around 8%. That was the case with S√£o Martinho‚Äôs plant expansion in Boa Vista, Goi√°s state. Inpasa, Brazil‚Äôs leading corn ethanol producer, has funded its projects entirely with cash flow. 

 Another key driver for the surge in projects was the increase in the permitted blend of anhydrous ethanol in gasoline, enabled by Brazil‚Äôs Future Fuel Law. The law allows the government to raise the blend to as much as 35%, pending technical studies. 

Biodiesel and soy 

 The biodiesel production chain also saw multi-billion reais in investment announcements in 2025, though on a smaller scale. Soy processors planned at least R$5.9 billion in investments through September 2026, according to the Brazilian Association of Vegetable Oil Industries (ABIOVE). 

 These investments are focused on soybean crushing and oil refining and represent a 2.4% increase over the previous 12-month period. 

 In addition to ABIOVE‚Äôs tally, one of the highlights in 2025 was a R$1 billion investment announced by Fr√≠sia Cooperativa Agroindustrial, based in Carambe√≠, Paran√° state. The plan includes a soybean crushing facility and warehouses in the states of Tocantins and Paran√°, as well as expansions in other business lines such as dairy, pork, seeds, and forestry. 

 Daniel Furlan Amaral, ABIOVE‚Äôs director of economics and regulatory affairs, said the investments are largely aimed at meeting domestic demand for soybean oil used in food and biofuel production. 

 ‚ÄúWithout biodiesel, Brazil‚Äôs crushing capacity would likely be much smaller. Oil production has been the main lever for increasing soybean meal output, which has helped lower animal feed costs and encouraged both semi-confinement and full confinement in livestock farming,‚Äù he said. 

 Meatpackers announced at least R$1.54 billion in domestic investments last year, and an additional $1.06 billion abroad, according to Valor‚Äôs tally. Most of the capital will go toward expanding production lines at existing plants to meet rising global meat demand. 

 Another R$7.6 billion in investments covered other agribusiness segments, from dairy and coffee to fertilizers, seeds, and potato processing plants. Argentine agribusiness firm GDM alone pledged R$1 billion over five years, while Brazilian cooperative Coamo announced a R$3 billion investment in a new port terminal in Itapo√°, in Santa Catarina state, slated to begin operations in 2030\. 

 Serigatti, from FGV, said that despite Brazil‚Äôs benchmark interest rate being at 15%, which discourages investments, ‚Äúin the long term, the fundamentals support agribusiness as one of the most investment-intensive sectors.‚Äù ‚ÄúAmong the country‚Äôs major industries, it has been the most successful in integrating into global value chains. It benefits from both a strong domestic economy and favorable conditions in international markets,‚Äù he added. 

 Citibank analysts also see growing global demand for food, with Brazil standing out as one of the few regions with significant potential to expand agricultural output. According to the bank, investments are being driven by the expansion of grain acreage‚Äîparticularly through pastureland conversion‚Äîand the growth of biofuel production. 

 However, Citi forecasts a potential decline in agribusiness investments in 2026\. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs due to the current challenging environment, marked by high leverage, elevated base rates, tight credit, and squeezed margins for producers. We believe most companies will prioritize resilience and debt reduction over the next year,‚Äù said Citi analysts Gabriel Barra and Renata Cabral.

Steel giant fails in bid to block docks redevelopment

15 Jan 2026 By Ben Vogel

The High Court has dismissed a judicial review request brought by steel manufacturer ArcelorMittal against plans to redevelop the Chatham Docks industrial site in Kent.

Developer Peel Waters was granted outline planning permission by Medway Council in November 2024 to demolish and redevelop the 31,000 square metre site.

It includes the land currently used by ArcelorMittal for its only UK site.

Peel Waters aims to create a new waterside business and enterprise campus, but ArcelorMittal‚Äôs Kent Wire subsidiary was allowed last April to apply for a judicial review.

Luxembourg-based ArcelorMittal had previously warned that it would leave the UK market if the development ‚Äì known as Basin 3 ‚Äì proceeded.

The High Court judgment rejected the manufacturer‚Äôs argument that the scheme would allow primary office use, which was not applied for.

ArcelorMittal also claimed Medway Council‚Äôs planning committee had been provided with misleading information about the use of space for general industrial, storage and distribution purposes.

But the judgment rejected this argument, adding that it erroneously ‚Äúcast the committee‚Äôs members in the role of pre-reformation churchgoers with the planning officers as priests, so that the former were unable to understand the underlying texts except through the mediation of the latter‚Äù.

It also said the information given to the committee was ‚Äúaccurate‚Äù and ‚Äúnot materially misleading‚Äù.

Loading‚Ä¶

Another strand in ArcelorMittal‚Äôs argument was that part of the Medway Local Plan 2003 to protect industrial and storage uses had been misinterpreted.

But the court concluded the Basin 3 development proposals were ‚Äúin broad accordance‚Äù with the Medway Local Plan‚Äôs aims, and had not been misapplied.

ArcelorMittal also raised concerns about potential changes of use for residential development, but the court dismissed this prospect as ‚Äúremote‚Äù and not ‚Äúmandatorily relevant‚Äù.

Responding to the High Court judgment, Peel Waters development director Leigh Thomas said: ‚ÄúWe welcome the decision to dismiss the judicial review and are pleased that Medway Council‚Äôs robust approval process has been upheld.

‚ÄúThis means we can now move forward with our plans for Basin 3, transforming underused brownfield land into a modern, high-quality employment campus that will triple the number of jobs on site and attract businesses aligned with Medway‚Äôs growth sectors.‚Äù

ArcelorMittal declined to comment on the judgment when contacted by Construction News.

The firm has produced reinforced concrete steel at Chatham Docks for projects including HS2, Thames Tideway and Crossrail, and the firm was also hoping to supply the Lower Thames Crossing.

Steel reinforcement produced at Chatham is used for fabric reinforcement, bespoke rebar, prefabricated elements and wire products for the precast industry.

Its chief executive Phil Taylor previously warned that Basin 3 would be ‚Äúcatastrophic‚Äù for the firm and a ‚Äúsignificant loss to the UK construction industry‚Äù.

Speaking to CN in May 2024, he said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre a principal supplier of steel reinforcement for the UK construction industry.

‚ÄúIn sum, around 30 per cent of the reinforcement supply requirements in the UK come out of the facility at Chatham Docks.‚Äù

Inland Tug Operations

Construction begins on river tugs for Brazilian operator Hermasa

Hermasa's new 30-metre pusher tugRobert Allan Ltd

Jens Karsten

Published on: 

19 Jan 2026, 1:22 am

Copied

Follow Us:

Construction recently began on two new pusher tugs in a series ordered by Brazilian river transport company Hermasa Navegacao da Amazonia.

The tugs were designed by Canadian naval architecture firm Robert Allan Ltd and will be tailored to the unique conditions of the Madeira River system in Brazil's Amazon region.

The vessels will handle barges transporting grain in the region. Once in service, they will be able to operate on B100 biodiesel as well as conventional marine diesel.

The tugs will be designed for shallow-draught operation, enabling safe and efficient navigation throughout the Amazon River basin. When completed, each vessel will be capable of pushing up to 20 barges with a combined cargo capacity of 32,000 tonnes.

Each tug will have an LOA of 30 metres, a moulded beam of 12 metres, a moulded depth of 3.2 metres, a draught of only 2.3 metres, and accommodation for up to 10 crewmembers.

The vessels will be designed to Brazilian flag rules and will be certified as inland navigating vessels by the American Bureau of Shipping under the class notation ‚ú† A1 River Service, Towing Vessel, ‚ú† AMS.

Planning & Construction News

 Giant crawler crane coming to UK

January 16, 2026 

364

The LR12500-1.0 has a max-rated load capacity of 2,500 tonnes, with a maximum hoist height of 200 metres and a operating reach up to 180 metres

Mammoet has purchased two new giant crawler cranes, one of which is already confirmed for an unnamed UK project.

As projects such as wind turbines get taller, the machinery to install them grows in tandem. The Liebherr LR11350 and LR12500-1.0 cranes acquired by Mammoet will enable the company‚Äôs ambitions for growth in the renewables sector.

 Liebherr released the LR12500-1.0 to the global market in 2022

The LR12500-1.0 is one of the largest crawler cranes made by Liebherr, beaten only by its bigger LR13000 sibling ‚Äì a 3,000t capacity crawler that Mammoet also has in its fleet.

The LR11350 has a maximum load capacity of 1,350t and a hoist height of 220 meters. It will join ten other machines that Mammoet has in its fleet with a capacity of 1,000 to 1,350t.

The LR12500-1.0‚Äôs 2,500t lifting power comes from its wide main boom. It has a hoist height of 200 meters, and its modular design makes it easy to transport.

Hinkley Point C‚Äôs Big Carl can lift twice as many tonnes as the LR12500-1.0 across a radius of 40 metres. But that crane is fixed on a ring and mounted platform, meaning it lacks the crawler crane‚Äôs ability to move itself.

The giant crawler crane will be the eleventh in Mammoet‚Äôs fleet with a capacity of between 1,000 to 1,350 tonnes

Peter van Oostrom, Global Projects and Assets director at Mammoet, said: ‚ÄúTo ensure we continue to have a crane fleet best fitting market requirements and most modern fleet of cranes in the world, it is important that we invest in new machines from leading manufacturers.

‚ÄúLiebherr is a worldwide supplier and the logical choice for cranes of this capacity.

‚ÄúWe therefore see it being in very high demand, particularly for offshore wind projects‚Äù.

Christoph Kleiner, managing director at Liebherr said: ‚ÄúMammoet has been a key partner to Liebherr for many years, providing valuable input into the development of new crane hardware. Its insight into usability and future capacity requirements is invaluable.

‚ÄúWe have a strong relationship with Mammoet and are delighted it has added two more Liebherr cranes to its world-class fleet‚Äù.

The two cranes are scheduled to work on key upcoming projects in the UK (LR12500-1.0) and the Netherlands (LR11350).

Lindsey refining ends, but Phillips 66 asset deal underscores strategic value of UK energy infrastructure

The confirmation that refining will not restart at Lindsey Oil Refinery marks another contraction in the UK‚Äôs domestic refining capacity.

7 January 2026 

 2 min read

However, the agreement by Phillips 66 to acquire key assets at the site has been broadly welcomed across the fuels sector as a move that preserves strategically important infrastructure at a time of heightened energy uncertainty.

Following the announcement, industry voices have been quick to underline both the opportunities and the inherent risks, particularly around energy security, policy direction and employment.

 Capacity loss highlights pressure on UK refining

Fuels Industry UK chief executive Elizabeth de Jong said the integration of the Lindsey assets into Phillips 66‚Äôs Humber operations would prevent the permanent loss of infrastructure that could play a vital role in the UK‚Äôs future energy system.

She welcomed the involvement of an experienced and reputable operator but warned that the announcement nonetheless confirms a further reduction in national refining capacity.

‚ÄúThe closure of another refinery underlines how difficult domestic fuel refining has become in a hostile regulatory environment,‚Äù she said, adding that the erosion of manufacturing capability was ‚Äúbad for the UK‚Äôs industrial and energy future‚Äù.

De Jong called on government to act with greater urgency, urging commitment to a firm timeline for a carbon border mechanism that would level carbon costs between domestic producers and imports. Without decisive policy intervention, she warned, further closures could follow, leaving the UK increasingly dependent on overseas supply at a time of growing geopolitical and energy risk.

Fuels Industry UK noted that refining and the wider fuels supply chain still meets around 47% of national final energy demand and underpins the development of lower-carbon fuels and industrial clusters, making the safeguarding of remaining capacity critical.

Union concern over jobs and site future

Trade union Unite struck a more cautionary note, warning that the Lindsey site must not simply be mothballed and repurposed as storage.

General secretary Sharon Graham described Lindsey as ‚Äúa critical piece of UK energy infrastructure‚Äù, stressing its historic role in supplying diesel and supporting hundreds of skilled jobs.

‚ÄúPhillips 66 should not be allowed to just mothball the site and turn it into a glorified storage tank,‚Äù she said, calling on government to work with the company to ensure the transaction protects employment and strengthens national energy security rather than undermining it.

Unite has confirmed it will seek consultations with Phillips 66 to understand its plans for the site and its workforce.

 Strategic relevance beyond refining

From an industry and market perspective, the acquisition also serves as a reminder that refining may be ending at Lindsey, but its strategic relevance has not.

Daniel Webb, Head of Sales at Prema Energy, suggested the deal exposes a growing contradiction in UK energy policy.

‚ÄúOn the surface, Lindsey‚Äôs closure looks like another retreat from domestic refining capacity,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut underneath, the asset sale shows that infrastructure still has strategic value, even when the original industrial purpose no longer stacks up commercially.‚Äù

Webb argued that Phillips 66 is acquiring optionality rather than sentiment, pointing to the scarcity and long-term importance of tankage, pipelines, grid connections and port access.

‚ÄúIn a world of volatile geopolitics, disrupted shipping lanes and uncertain transition timelines, those assets act as insurance,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey can support fuel imports today, low-carbon fuels tomorrow, and technologies we haven‚Äôt fully committed to yet.‚Äù

He added that maintaining activity in the Humber region preserves the skills base and industrial ecosystem needed to manage, rather than abruptly impose, the energy transition.

‚ÄúRefining ends, but strategic relevance doesn‚Äôt,‚Äù Webb concluded.

 Secretary Naig announces 2026 renewable fuels marketing award recipients 

Staff Editor
Jan 14, 2026
Jan 14, 2026

Iowa Secretary of Agriculture Mike Naig today announced that Karde‚Äôs Convenience Store and Pilot Travel Centers are the recipients of the 2026 Renewable Fuels Marketing Awards. The annual awards recognize fuel retailers for outstanding leadership in expanding access to renewable fuels, educating consumers, and strengthening Iowa‚Äôs ethanol and biodiesel markets. He made the announcement during the annual Fuel Iowamembership breakfast in Des Moines.

‚ÄúCongratulations to Karde‚Äôs Convenience Store and Pilot Travel Centers, and thank you for your leadership in promoting ethanol and biodiesel,‚Äù said Secretary Naig. ‚ÄúRenewable fuels are a win for everyone. Consumers gain access to affordable, reliable, homegrown energy, and Iowa farmers benefit from stronger demand for corn and soybeans. Through investments in infrastructure, marketing, and consumer education, retailers like Karde‚Äôs and Pilot are expanding access to higher blends, saving consumers money, and helping make everyday life more affordable. We need to see biofuel use continue to expand across the country, including year-round nationwide access to E15 and greater utilization of biodiesel and renewable diesel.‚Äù

The 2026 Renewable Fuels Marketing Award recipients:

Ethanol Award ‚Äì Karde‚Äôs Convenience Store

Karde‚Äôs Convenience Store has demonstrated leadership in expanding renewable fuel access and consumer education in Monticello through targeted infrastructure investment and hands-on community engagement. In the summer of 2025, Karde‚Äôs installed E15 pumps, bringing the first clearly branded Unleaded 88 fueling options to the community. Building on that investment, Karde‚Äôs partnered with the Jones County Corn Growers to host a pump promotion in October 2025, where consumers fueling with Unleaded 88 received gift cards and education about ethanol-blended fuels. Store owner Mike Cox participated as a celebrity pumper, engaging directly with customers to answer questions and highlight fuel choices. The promotion resulted in approximately 900 additional gallons sold above the store‚Äôs daily average, underscoring the impact of proactive marketing and consumer outreach. Karde‚Äôs plans to continue these efforts with another promotion in spring 2026, reinforcing its commitment to growing consumer fuel choice and celebrating the use of homegrown ethanol at the pump.

Biodiesel Award ‚Äì Pilot Travel Centers

In 2025, Pilot Travel Centers launched a pioneering B99 biodiesel pump at its Des Moines location, making it one of only a few sites nationwide offering nearly pure biodiesel for commercial trucking fleets. Developed through a collaboration with PepsiCo and Optimus Technologies, the project demonstrated how innovative engine technology and strategic partnerships can enable fleets to operate seamlessly on higher biodiesel blends. The launch generated extensive media interest and helped raise awareness of biodiesel‚Äôs performance and emissions-reduction benefits, while highlighting Iowa‚Äôs leadership in renewable fuels. The project also underscored the role fuel retailers can play in expanding access to practical, scalable, homegrown energy solutions that support fleet decarbonization and strengthen rural economies.

The Secretary‚Äôs Renewable Fuels Marketing Awards annually recognize Iowa fuel retailers and marketers who demonstrate innovation, commitment, and measurable success in promoting renewable fuels such as ethanol and biodiesel. Award recipients showcase how infrastructure investment, strategic partnerships, and consumer outreach can expand renewable fuel use while supporting Iowa farmers, strengthening rural economies, and advancing practical, lower-carbon, homegrown energy solutions.

To see past winners and to learn more about renewable fuels in Iowa, visit IowaAgriculture.gov.

 Biodiesel Reduces Ship‚Äôs Black Carbon Emissions by up to 81 Percent

in International Shipping News,Shipping: Emission Possible 16/01/2026 

New Danish data, collected during real-world sailing, documents significant climate benefits from biofuel for the shipping industry. The findings have been submitted to the International Maritime Organization (IMO).

Soot particles ‚Äì also known as Black Carbon ‚Äì are among the most harmful emissions from shipping, both for the climate, where they contribute to global warming and melting of Arctic ice, and for public health through poor air quality. Now, experts from the CLEANSHIP project document that using biodiesel, specifically B100 FAME, during normal operation can reduce Black Carbon emissions by up to 81 percent compared to traditional marine gas oil (MGO).

The measurements were carried out on the Uni-Tankers vessel Falstria Swan, where an advanced online Black Carbon sensor from Green Instruments, developed in collaboration with Danish Technological Institute, made it possible to track emissions in detail and in real time during the vessel‚Äôs normal operation.

‚ÄúWe expected that biofuel would lead to cleaner combustion, but the magnitude of the reduction ‚Äì especially at lower engine loads ‚Äì is a very positive surprise. This demonstrates that biodiesel can reduce not only net CO‚ÇÇ, but also Black Carbon, which is highly significant for the shipping sector‚Äôs total climate footprint. At the same time, the measurement technology allows us to monitor emissions with much greater detail than ever before,‚Äù says Simon Bastrup Spangenberg, consultant and measurement specialist in alternative fuels and emission reduction at Danish Technological Institute.

For Uni-Tankers, the measurements translate directly into new, practical knowledge: ‚ÄúThe latest real-world sailing data on biodiesel (B100) give us a clear picture of both the black carbon footprint and actual CO‚ÇÇ emissions. This insight is crucial for achieving our own reduction targets, while also contributing to better, data-driven recommendations for reducing emissions across the shipping industry,‚Äù says Troels Reppien, Technical Director at Uni-Tankers.

Although biodiesel demonstrates a significant reduction in Black Carbon, current global production of biofuel can only cover a small share of the global fleet‚Äôs total energy demand. Therefore, the Cleanship project continues to analyse data and work towards recommendations on how Black Carbon and other emissions can be effectively reduced in shipping.

The results from the measurement campaign have now been submitted to the International Maritime Organization (IMO) in the form of a white paper. This documentation will contribute to the international efforts to reduce Black Carbon emissions ‚Äì especially in Arctic regions, where soot particles have a particularly significant climate impact on ice and the environment. The white paper is scheduled for consideration at IMO‚Äôs 13th session of the Sub-Committee on Pollution Prevention and Response (PPR), which will take place from 9‚Äì13 February 2026. 
Source: CLEANSHIP Project

MOL PLUS to Invest in Pyxis to Advance Electric Vessel Deployment

Maritime Activity Reports, Inc.

January 13, 2026 

(Credit: MOL PLUS)

MOL PLUS has decided to invest in Pyxis Maritime, a Singapore-based developer of electric vessels and operator of electric boat charging stations, as part of efforts to promote the commercialization of electric vessels and related infrastructure.

The investment comes as Singapore advances toward its national net-zero target for 2050\. From 2030, all new harbor craft operating in the Port of Singapore will be required to be fully electric, capable of using B100 biofuel, or compatible with net-zero fuels such as hydrogen.

MOL PLUS said the investment is intended to accelerate the social implementation and commercialization of electric vessels and charging infrastructure together with Pyxis. In addition to providing capital, MOL PLUS will support Pyxis‚Äô technology and business development and facilitate business collaboration by drawing on resources within and outside the MOL Group.

The partnership brings together startup-led innovation with operational expertise in shipping, ports and fleet management, reflecting growing industry alignment around maritime electrification.

Separately, on November 12, 2025, MOL (Asia Oceania) signed a heads of agreement with Pyxis to study the potential establishment of an integrated business model to promote electric vessels and charging infrastructure.

Pyxis is a maritime electrification technology start-up focused on the development and manufacturing of electric vessels and the operation of charging stations. The company aims to support mass commercialization and adoption of electric coastal vessels to accelerate maritime decarbonisation while improving vessel performance and management.

MOL PLUS is the corporate venture arm of the MOL Group, working with startup companies to generate new businesses and value for the shipping industry.
