 Introduction

Current compression ignition (CI) engines operate on liquid fuels, which are primarily derived from crude oil. Crude oil is refined to produce diesel, a commonly used liquid fuel. However, due to the growing demand for fossil fuels, the depletion of oil reserves, and increasingly stringent pollution regulations, researchers are showing increased interest in alternative fuels. One such alternative is biodiesel, which is produced from plant and animal fats. Biodiesel consists of long-chain alkyl esters derived from these fats. It is commonly produced through a process known as transesterification, in which vegetable oils or animal fats chemically react with an alcohol to produce biodiesel. When methanol is used as the alcohol, the resulting product is fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) the most common form of biodiesel. Although ethanol can also be used, methanol is preferred due to its lower cost.

Biodiesel can be made from both edible and non-edible plant oils such as soybean oil1."), jatropha oil2 and Tyre Pyrolysis Oil (TPO) blends. Fuel 108, 699‚Äì708. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fuel.2012.12.042

 (2013)."),3."), rubber seed oil4, palm oil5."), mango seed oil6."), mahua oil7."),8."), cottonseed oil9."), lignocellulosic materials10."), canola oil11."), linseed oil12."), algae oil13."), industrial waste oil14."), corn oil15."), olive oil 16."), wheat starch17."), and cassava18."). Numerous studies have already been conducted on the performance of biodiesel derived from these sources. In addition to being a viable fuel for CI engines, biodiesel is also a low-carbon substitute for heating oil. It offers several advantages, including higher cetane numbers and excellent lubricity, which helps extend the lifespan of high-pressure diesel injection systems and reduces wear in the fuel system. Biodiesel contains no sulfur and is often blended with ultra-low sulfur diesel to enhance lubricity. Biodiesel is biodegradable and emits fewer pollutants without releasing toxic substances. Biodiesel blends can be used in existing CI engines with little or no modification. As the volumetric concentration of biodiesel increases, Sauter mean diameter (SMD) values also rise. These values are directly influenced by the thermophysical properties of the fuel 19."). Because biodiesel has higher viscosity and surface tension than conventional diesel, biodiesel-diesel blends exhibit larger SMD values. Nevertheless, the fuel spray penetration of these blends remains comparable to that of pure diesel20.").

Waste cooking oils (WCOs) are advantageous second-generation biodiesel feedstocks that can be utilized as a sustainable energy source21."). The staggering volume of WCOs generated worldwide has led to significant societal, economic, and environmental concerns. It is estimated that approximately 15 million tonnes of WCOs are produced globally each year22."),23. A large portion of WCOs consists of triglycerides, monoglycerides, and diglycerides. Additionally, free fatty acids (FFAs) are present, typically ranging from 5 to 20% by weight. Triglycerides, composed of both unsaturated and saturated fatty acids, are commonly used as base chemicals in various industries to produce high-value products24.").

Biodiesel derived from waste cooking oil is currently being explored as an attractive alternative fuel due to its low emissions, biodegradability, non-toxic nature, and near-zero carbon footprint25."). In recent years, this type of biodiesel has gained significant popularity. However, there are certain drawbacks associated with the long-term use of WCO biodiesel, including reduced thermal efficiency, carbon deposits on valves, and scuffing of piston rings in engines26 doped with alumina nano-additives. Sci Rep 2024;14:16228."). One of the most important concerns is the stability of biodiesel, especially when produced from used cooking oil. A major issue is the high viscosity of WCO biodiesel, which negatively affects atomization and pumping properties when used in CI engines. To mitigate these disadvantages, the viscosity of clean biodiesel should be reduced as much as possible. One study found that using zinc oxide nanoparticles combined with tungsten phosphoric acid as a catalyst can reduce peroxide levels and increase the stability of used cooking oil biodiesel blends27."). This type of solid acid catalyst (SAC) used in the transesterification process also has a minor influence on fuel properties. Additionally, the brake thermal efficiency (BTE) of WCO biodiesel blends was found to be higher than that of conventional diesel blends. Calcium oxide (CaO) nanoparticles, when synthesized and used as additives, also appear to be a promising option for enhancing the combustion properties of engines running on WCO biodiesel blends28.").

However, one disadvantage of using esters is their high viscosity, which leads to various challenges, including cold starting. To address this issue, alcohol fuels such as ethanol and butanol can be added to biodiesel-diesel blends to improve their overall fuel properties. This addition helps increase engine performance and combustion efficiency, while simultaneously reducing harmful pollutants like smoke and particulates29."). Given the growing concerns about alcohol-based biofuels and biodiesel, an alternative and expanded approach to mixing alcohol with both diesel and biodiesel is being actively explored. This strategy may alleviate some of the current concerns associated with biodiesel, as high-alcohol pentanol has been shown to improve fuel quality30."). Owing to the its superior fuel properties, high-alcohol pentanol could potentially mitigate some of the recent challenges faced in biodiesel fuel usage. At lower percentages, alcohols can be blended with diesel fuel. Due to their higher latent heat of vaporization and lower net calorific value, alcohols are commonly used in blends. Additionally, because alcohols promote low-temperature combustion, their incorporation into base gasoline significantly reduces NOx emissions31.").

Lower C-H chain alcohols, such as ethanol and methanol, have been used in several studies as blended fuels; however, this often leads to phase separation and poor ignition characteristics32 mode. Fuel 170, 49‚Äì59 (2016)."). Alcohols with longer C-H chains and comparatively higher calorific values, such as butanol, pentanol, and octanol, are potential additives to diesel‚Äìbiodiesel blends to mitigate these issues. Several studies have shown that adding these higher C-H alcohols to diesel helps reduce CO and NOx emissions. Alcohols with more than 4 carbon atoms (up to 10 carbon atoms) are considered higher alcohols, which are typically more viscous and oily. Alcohols with more than 12 carbon atoms are solid at room temperature. Alcohols such as butanol, pentanol, propanol, and octanol, which have longer C-H chains and higher calorific values, can be added to diesel and biodiesel to reduce emissions and improve fuel economy. However, certain stabilizers are required to homogenize diesel-alcohol and biodiesel-alcohol mixtures. These stabilizers are relatively expensive, which increases the overall fuel cost. To address this, several studies have been conducted to eliminate the need for stabilizers, leading to the development of ternary blends.

When 10‚Äì15% biodiesel is added to diesel-alcohol blends, phase stratification is reduced, creating a novel fuel blend known as the ternary fuel blend33."). This approach results in a fuel that is less expensive than conventional diesel. Therefore, a ternary fuel mixture of diesel, alcohol, and biodiesel could serve as a viable alternative fuel for current diesel engines. The use of a ternary mixture of waste cooking oil biodiesel, higher alcohols, and diesel in CI engines has been rarely explored.

Nano-additives are widely used to investigate the effects of biodiesel‚Äìdiesel blends on ignition delay (ID) and combustion34.") 35."). When nano-additives are added to fuels like gasoline or diesel, they act as viscosity reducers, enhancing combustion activity. Metal oxide nanoparticles can also promote secondary atomization processes, thereby improve thermal efficiency and reduce emissions36."). The combination of biodiesel and nano-additive leads to enhanced combustion quality, which in turn increases the engine‚Äôs thermal efficiency. When added to fuel, these metal-based nanoparticles exhibit a natural catalytic effect on hydrocarbon combustion reducing ID and soot ignition temperature while increasing the energy density of the fuel blend. Recently, a variety of nano-additives have been explored to enhance engine performance. However, the optimal concentration of nano-additives required to improve performance and minimize emissions in diesel engines remains unclear37."). Therefore, it is essential to identify the ideal ratio of nano-additives in relation to engine parameters, without compromising performance or emissions. Taguchi method has been recognized as an effective strategy for multi-objective optimization, including engine development. Nonetheless, limited research has explored the effects of blend concentration and nanoparticle dosage as independent variables to achieve optimal engine performance and minimal emissions38 2 and CaO nanostructures. J. Exp. Nanosci. 5, 93‚Äì105 (2010).").

Based on insights from the literature, the current research focuses on analyzing the potential use of a ternary blend in a CI engine. This study aims to improve engine performance and reduce emissions by utilizing ternary blends of WCO biodiesel, alcohol, and diesel, supplemented with Al2O3 nanoparticles, as fuel in a direct injection (DI) diesel engine. The primary objective of this research is to examine how these ternary blends, in combination with nanoparticles, influence emissions, combustion characteristics, and engine performance. The study addresses a significant research gap, the lack of comprehensive investigation into the specific combination of alcohol, Al2O3 nanoparticles, and WCO biodiesel in diesel engines. Key contributions of this research include assessing the feasibility of these blends as sustainable alternatives to conventional diesel, and identifying the optimal blend ratios that enhance engine performance while minimizing emissions. This study highlights the potential of WCO biodiesel‚Äìalcohol‚Äìdiesel blends as a competitive and environmentally friendly substitute for fossil diesel. It also provides guidance on ideal blend ratios to improve performance and reduce harmful exhaust emissions. Additionally, the study offers valuable insights into the role of Al2O3 nanoparticles in enhancing combustion and reducing emissions. Ultimately, it underscores the viability of using waste cooking oil as a sustainable feedstock for biodiesel production, thereby supporting circular economy initiatives.

The key merits of this research lie in its focus on sustainability, the exploration of novel fuel blend combinations, and the potential for improved engine performance. While the study specifically investigates a diesel engine, the findings may be applicable to a wide variety of diesel-powered vehicles. However, the study also has certain limitations. Additionally, the research acknowledges that biodiesel blends can lead to increased NOx emissions, highlighting the need for further investigation and the development of effective mitigation strategies. Moreover, long-term studies are necessary to assess the durability and reliability of engines running on these blends. The use of biodiesel can sometimes result in issues such as carbon deposits or piston ring scuffing, which may affect engine longevity. To reduce dependence on fossil fuels, this study demonstrates that WCO biodiesel‚Äìalcohol‚Äìdiesel blends have strong potential as competitive alternatives to conventional diesel fuel. It offers recommendations for optimal blend ratios that enhance engine performance while reducing harmful emissions. Furthermore, the research provides insights into how Al2O3 nanoparticles can further improve combustion efficiency and emissions control. Finally, it emphasizes the potential of using waste cooking oil as a sustainable feedstock for biodiesel production, thereby supporting circular economy initiatives.

 Biodiesel production

Cleaned waste cooking oils were collected from the kitchen of Sathyabama Institute of Science and Technology, where the oil is used for frying various food items. Initially, the FFA content of the oil samples was measured, followed by the transesterification process. Sodium hydroxide pellets (caustic soda) were used as a catalyst. Methanol was mixed with dry sodium hydroxide pellets to dissolve them. A solution of 180 ml of methanol and 3.75 g of NaOH pellets was thoroughly stirred for 30 min. This mixture of alcohol and catalyst was then added to the oil in a conical flask. A magnetic stirrer, running at 300 rpm, was used to mix the fluid evenly for two and a half hours at a constant reaction temperature of 60 ¬∞C. Initially, the catalyst reacts with the FFA in the oil, forming soap. The presence of water and free fatty acids in the oil can lead to the formation of emulsions with methanol or oil, which may hinder the reaction. These emulsions were discarded. After the reaction was completed and the alcohol was removed, the solution was left to settle for 24 h, allowing the methyl ester and glycerin layers to separate completely. Due to the difference in density, glycerin, being denser, settled at the bottom and was drained off, leaving the methyl esters (biodiesel) as the upper layer. The transesterification process is shown in Fig. 3.

Fig. 3

Transesterified waste cooking oil.

Full size image

The esters are stored after the glycerine has been extracted and they have been washed with warm water to remove the leftover residues. A flask separator was used to extract the methyl esters from sedimentation. The biodiesel was washed with 10% water until it reached the desired purity. Following this, it was dried using a dryer and then placed under an electric fan for 12 h to ensure complete drying. The control factors of the biodiesel production process are presented in Table 2.

Preparation of nano alumina

The solution gelation method, which entailed dissolving the sample of 25 g of aluminium nitrate in the citric acid with 0.5 as the molar ratio, was used to create alumina nanoparticles. With continuous stirring and heated at 80 ¬∞C the solution is gelled. After being dried for 10 h at 90 ¬∞C, the gel was melted at 1055 ¬∞C to produce a white powder as shown in Fig. 4. Figure 5 displays the X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Al2O3. Diffraction peaks of Al2O3 at 2Œ∏ values are 33¬∞, 38¬∞, 52¬∞, 64¬∞, 68¬∞, 78¬∞. It confirmed that the Al2O3 powder has cubic phases and agreed by the file No. 46‚Äì1212 of standard JCPDS-ICDD.  Blend preparation and fuel properties

The sonicating method is used to combine biodiesel-diesel with alcohol. Hielscher brand ultrasonic mixing reactor was used for blending alchols with biodiesel and diesel. In this investigation, a bioruptor system consisting of a water bath and high-powered ultrasound generators beneath the tank was employed. The Bioruptor and probe sonicator generate ultrasonic radiation at the same frequency (20 kHz). When a metallic bar comes into and touches the sample, it assists to transmit the ultrasonic waves into the tubes. This metallic patented resonance bar reflects ultrasound from the bath, increasing the sonication efficiency. After the biodiesel is mixed with diesel and alcohol, it is placed in the ultrasonicator and agitated for 30 to 45 min to produce a homogeneous blend.

Three types of blends with biodiesel and diesel were prepared from each alcohol. Table 4 gives the acronym and constituents of the prepared blends for this study. The biodiesel samples are tested for fuel properties as per the ASTM standards and shown in Table 5. The characteristics reveal that the manufactured fuel samples fall within the ASTM standards, and these fuels may be used to power a CI engine. All these blends were tested in engine without and with 25ppm and 50ppm of nano additive additions.

 Brake thermal efficiency

The BTE values in Table 6 demonstrate that; the diesel has greater thermal efficiency values. Its high calorific value is the reason for this. Out of all the higher alcohol ternary lends tested, n-pentanol ternary fuel blends outperformed compared to all other tested blends40."),41."),42."). The mean BTE values of all the blends were increased by 4% when 50ppm of Al2O3 nano additives are added average at all tested loads. The mean BTE value increases by a very less amount of 0.3% when 25ppm of Al2O3 nano additives are added average for all tested loads. It turns out that the performance of blends is not significantly affected by the 25ppm of nano additive addition. The BTE values for the diesel and the ternary mixtures increase with increase in engine load and reaches a maximum at 75% load and after that finds a drop. At lower load condition, straight diesel achieved greater efficiency values than the blends at all three injection pressures.

Brake specific energy consumption

Brake specific fuel consumption (BSEC) is known as the amount of fuel utilized per unit power developed per unit time. It primarily depends on the properties of the fuel, particularly its heating value. However, the BSEC is calculated based on the density of the fuel only. For comparing different fuel types with different calorific values, brake specific energy consumption (BSEC) values are appropriate. The Figs. 9, 10 and 11 show the variations of BSEC values against engine load for the straight D100, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without and with 50ppm and 25ppm Al2O3 nano particles. As the biodiesel concentration in the blend is more, the BSEC value for each biofuel mixture increases steadily. Of all the tested blends, the pentanol ternary biodiesel blends Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60 and Pe10B30D60 produced less BSEC values44."),[45](/articles/s41598-025-26974-2ref-CR45 "Park, S. Exhaust gas temperature

One of the output factors that quantifies how much heat is lost is the engine‚Äôs exhaust gas temperature (EGT). The EGT values of D100, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without and with 50ppm and 25ppm Al2O3 nano particles are depicted in Figs. 12, 13 and 14 respectively.

Under all circumstances, blends of biofuel have produced higher EGT values than pure diesel. If the biodiesel concentration in the blend rose, the EGT value for each biofuel blend decrease steadily. On comparing the blends, pentanol ternary biodiesel blends Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60 and Pe10B30D60 produced lesser EGT values followed by butanol ternary biofuel blends. The results revealed that nano additive definitely boosted the EGT values. The EGT values for all the blends were increased by 5 to 6% on average when 50ppm of Al2O3 nano additives at all loads. The average EGT value increases approximately by 1.5% when 25ppm of Al2O3 nano additives are added at all loads. It turns out that the EGT value is affected slightly by the inclusion of nano additive addition. nano additive added blends would have increased the combustion temperature in turn results increase in EGT for all the blends. High cylinder temperature during the combustion causes more heat transfer from the cylinder walls which in turn rises the EGT values. As the load increases, the EGT values for both diesel and biodiesel blend raised. The full load state in this study showed greater EGT values for all blends because larger loads result in higher combustion temperatures. As the load rises, extra fuel is pumped into the cylinder, raising the EGT to maintain the same power output. The fuel‚Äôs oxygen concentration enhances combustion, raising the EGT. The increased ID and intrinsic oxygen content are the causes of the greater combustion temperature.

 Heat release rate

Heat release rate (HRR) is known as the amount of heat spawned during combustion in the engine cylinder. This heat is utilized for shaft work and to heat the working medium, increasing its internal energy. Some portion of the heat is lost with the cooling water through cylinder walls as well as cylinder heads. The Figs. 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23 shows the variations of heat release rate in kJ/m3deg against crank angle (¬∞CA) for Diesel, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without nano additive addition and with 50ppm and 25ppm Al2O3 addition at zero load, half load and full load respectively. The biodiesel blends and pure diesel show rapid premixed combustion trailed by the diffused combustion. Fast burning of the pre-mixed blend, followed by fast heat release and dispersed combustion, occur shortly after the delay time. The combustion rate is determined by the available flammable air‚Äìfuel combination. The pre-mixed combustion for the biodiesel blends is extremely quick, according to the study‚Äôs heat release rate curves. The residual combustion will continue throughout the expansion stroke.

The maximum peak pressure recorded by individual fuel blends in the study occurred at full load. More growth of combustion temperature and pressure is ascribed to higher loads50."). Complete combustion is ensured when the ignition lag shortens when the load rises. Shortly after TDC, the biodiesel types examined in the study under all circumstances reached their maximal pressure levels.

Upon increasing the engine load the ID declines for all the tested fuel blends. Since biodiesel has a higher cetane number than diesel, which resulted shorter ID when used in CRDI engines with ternary blends of diesel, biodiesel, and higher alcohol[51](/articles/s41598-025-26974-2#ref-CR51 "Sharma A, Murugan S. Nitrogen oxides

Nitrogen oxide (NOX) generation in CI engines is caused by a longer retention period and a higher flame temperature54. Compared to diesel, the biodiesel blends have a higher oxygen content[55](/articles/s41598-025-26974-2ref-CR55 "Sharma, A. & Murugan, S. Effect of blending waste tyre derived fuel on oxidation stability of biodiesel and performance and emission studies of a diesel engine. Appl. Therm. Eng. 118, 365‚Äì374. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.applthermaleng.2017.03.008

 (2017)."). This oxygen from the fuel promotes the production of NOX. Under all circumstances, blends of biofuel have produced more NOx values than pure diesel. If the biodiesel concentration in the blend rose, the NOx value for each biofuel blend decrease steadily. The pentanol ternary biodiesel blends Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60 and Pe10B30D60 produced higher EGT values followed by butanol ternary biofuel blends. By comparing all the fuel blends, the pentanol blends produced greater NOX values. When the pressure and temperature is high almost all the injected fuel is burnt which leads to boosting up of peak cylinder temperature which in turn produces more NOX emissions. The trend is reversed for the other blends, i.e. the combustion will take place in power stroke which results in less peak temperature56."). The NOX emissions steadily rise in tandem with the load. The NOX emissions are lower at the initial load circumstances. Greater combustion temperatures brought on by further load increases result in noticeably greater NOX readings57.").

Carbon monoxides

Carbon monoxide (CO) is produced during the transitional phases of the oxidation of fuel. The interaction between the CO and the oxidants in the cylinder causes the oxidation from CO to CO2. The CO won‚Äôt be fully oxidized if there are insufficient oxidants, a low gas temperature, or a brief retention period. Carbon monoxide may be produced from extreme mixture ratios. The Figs. 39, 40, 41 show the CO emissions against the engine load for the straight diesel, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without nano additive addition, with 50ppm and 25 ppm Al2O3 nano additive addition at various engine loads, respectively. In comparison to pure diesel, with greater oxygen content, which encourages better oxidation, led to somewhat reduced CO emissions for the blends. However, the biofuel blends Bu20B20D60, Pr20B20D60, and Pr15B25D60 occasionally showed superior CO emissions particularly at lower load conditions. Their poor spray formation properties, which result from the lesser calorific values, are the source of the rise in CO. In contrast, the mixes Pe20B20D60, Pr10B30D60, and Pe10B30D60 generated reduced CO emissions due to their complete combustion and high oxygen concentration in biodiesel.

Smoke opacity

One kind of emission particle that is created when fuels are deposited on the walls of the cylinder is smoke60."). The Figs. 42, 43, 44 show the smoke opacity values against load for the straight diesel, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without nano additive addition, with 50ppm and 25 ppm Al2O3 nano additive addition at various engine loads, respectively. The smoke opacity ratings of the biofuel blends were greater than that of diesel. This is because blends of alcohol and biodiesel have heavy molecules, low volatility, and high viscosity. Because biofuel blends are poorly atomized, it is witnessed that the smoke values rises as the biodiesel concentration rises. Because of their light viscosity, the pentanol ternary blends burn better than their counterparts, resulting in somewhat lower smoke opacity ratings. It is learned that, the 50ppm nano additive addition recorded less the smoke opacity than the 25ppm addition. The complete combustion is realized in pentanol blends because of effective atomization, causing less smoke formation for these fuel types61."). The complete combustion could reduce the smoke formation for all the fuel types62."). The smoke opacity steadily increases as the load does63."). For every fuel type examined, the variations in the blends‚Äô values at lower loads are minimal.

 Unburnt hydrocarbons

Heterogeneous combustion is a feature of CI engine. Fuel evaporation and air‚Äìfuel mixing with unburned gases occur at the same time61."). The generation of unburned hydrocarbon (UHC) pollutants from this type of combustion is a complicated topic to examine. The generation of UHC during combustion is caused by very rich and lean mixes64."). Hydrocarbon emission, which quantifies the total amount of unburned hydrocarbon, can be used to demonstrate how complete a combustion process is. Biodiesel with a higher cetane number ignites faster and operates more efficiently, reducing hydrocarbon emissions65."). The slow mixing of ternary blends with air results in an over-rich mixture or quenching of the combustion reaction, and this can result in incomplete combustion products and high UHC in the exhaust gases. Incomplete combustion products and excess UHC in exhaust gases may result from an over-rich mixture or the quenching of the combustion reaction induced by the slow mixing of ternary mixes with air. The Figs. 45, 46, 47 show the HC emissions against load for the Diesel, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without nano additive addition, with 50ppm and 25 ppm Al2O3 nano additive addition at various engine loads, respectively.

When compared to diesel, the biodiesel blends show varying levels of UHC emissions. The ternary blends from butanol and propanol occasionally had higher UHC readings. These biodiesel kinds with higher viscosity and density characteristics have lower UHC emissions. Because of their high oxygen concentration and low viscosity, the pentanol ternary blends have somewhat lower UHC values than the other blends. The blends‚Äô UHC values fall as the amount of biodiesel rises. The UHC emission levels drop when the nano additive level in the blends is increased. By providing adequate space and time for full combustion, the increased injection pressure after adding the nano additives lowers the generation of UHC. Because it takes less time for full combustion for the blends without nano additives, the tendency is reversed. When the load increase, UHC emission also increases for all the tested fuels. But there is no much rise in the UHC emission values from Zero load to Maximum load condition. It demonstrates that load fluctuation has very little effect on the production of UHC. There will be fewer hydrocarbon emissions at higher flame temperatures. Since biodiesel has high oxygen concentration, it combusts more competently and releases less hydrocarbons. In the case of biodiesel mixes, it guarantees full combustion. These findings are consistent with some past studies66,67."). According to some studies, biodiesel alcohol blends greatly reduce UHC emissions and smoke26 doped with alumina nano-additives. Sci Rep 2024;14:16228."). Compared to those studies, the current study uses a higher percentage of alcohol (low cetane number) and biodiesel (increased viscosity), which comprises larger molecules. The evaporation rate slows as the droplet size grows due to the biodiesel‚Äôs high viscosity. Higher HC and smoke generation resulted from an increase in ID induced by alcohols‚Äô lower cetane number. A reduced evaporation rate might lead to an over-rich mixture or quench the combustion reaction, resulting in incomplete combustion products, HC, and smoke in the exhaust gases68.").

Grey relational analysis

Several strategies were employed to sort the relationship between multiple variables. One of those is the Grey relational method. The Taguchi method, which is based on Grey relational analysis, can be utilized to address multi-response problems69."),70. This method is used to optimize the concentration of the ternary blend in percentage of volume, the concentration of the Al2O3 nano additive, and the load percentage71."). The Grey relationship coefficients are calculated and the experimental results are standardized. These factors offer the connection between appropriate and actual values. The coefficients were then averaged to define grade values for the three process answers. The overall analysis of the several trial data is originated from the calculated Grey relational grades. The process for calculating the Grey grade relationship value is explained in the phases that follow.

Initially, the S/N ratio (Yij) was calculated from the original experimental data. The parameters brake thermal efficiency and cylinder pressure are set as greater the better-quality attributes since the parameters that result from the output need to be maximized. Equation (1) is used to get the S/N ratios for these values.

$$\\frac{{\\text{S}}}{{\\text{N}}}{\\text{Ratio}} = - 10{\\text{log }}\\left( {\\frac{1}{{\\text{n}}}} \\right)\\mathop \\sum \\limits\_{k = 0}^{n} 1/{\\text{Y}}^{2}$$

 (1)

It is necessary to limit the emission values, brake specific energy, HRR and EGT and to be set as the lower the better values. Equation (2) is used to get the S/N ratios from these values.

$$\\frac{{\\text{S}}}{{\\text{N}}}{\\text{ratio}} = - 10{\\text{log }}\\left( {\\frac{1}{{\\text{n}}}} \\right)\\mathop \\sum \\limits\_{k = 0}^{n} {\\text{y}}^{2}$$

 (2)

Next, the parameters‚Äô normalized values are computed. A normalization is done to scale the single input into an appropriate range and distribute it uniformly. The Eq. (3) is used to calculate these normalized values through transformation.

$$\\text{xi }( (\\text{k})=\\frac{yi \\left(k\\right)+\\text{min}yi (k)}{\\text{maxyi }\\left(\\text{k}\\right)-\\text{minyi }(\\text{k})}\\text{Yi}2$$

 (3)

The normalized lower the better values are calculated by using the Eq. (4)

$$\\text{xi }( (\\text{k})=\\frac{\\text{maxyi}\\left(\\text{k}\\right)-\\text{yi }(\\text{k})}{\\text{maxyi }\\left(\\text{k}\\right)-\\text{minyi }(\\text{k})}$$

 (4)

Eq. (5) was used to calculate the values of the Grey relational coefficients, or GCij. Equation (6) was used to determine the Grey relational grades (Gi) from the averaged Grey relational coefficients

$$\\text{GC} =\\frac{\\Delta \\text{min}+ \\lambda \\Delta max}{\\Delta \\mathit{ij} \\left(\\text{k}\\right)- \\lambda \\Delta max}$$

 (3.5)

$$\\text{Gi}= \\frac{1}{\\text{m}}{\\sum }\_{k=1}^{n}( \\text{GC})$$

 (3.6)

where;

S/N-signal to noise ratio

Yi-engine output parameter

Xi-normalized value

GC-Grey relational coefficient

Gi-Grey relational grade

Min-minimum

Max-maximum

The Experimental values, S/N ratios, Normalized S/N ratios, ‚àÜs, Grey relational coefficients and Grey relational grades of Butanol, pentanol and propanol-based ternary lends are included in the Appendices section after being tallied. The optimal levels of the single-response Grey grade Gi problem are studied through analysis.
The major effects of the butanol blends are shown in Table 8. the Taguchi‚Äôs Grey grade relational analysis found the optimum combination for the butanol blends as Bu10B30D60, 50% load, 50 ppm Al2O3 from the experimental values.
The major effects of the butanol blends are shown in Table 9. The optimum combination for the pentanol blends was found as Pe10B30D60, 100% load, 50 ppm Al2O3 from the experimental values.

 Conclusions

As per the experimental studies made on the diesel engine with the ternary blends of butanol, pentanol and propanol with waste cooking oil biodiesel and straight diesel with and without nano particle addition loading the following conclusions are made:

The addition Al2O3 nano additive concentration 50 ppm with the ternary blends improved the brake thermal efficiency values of 4% average for all the fuels tested. The brake specific energy consumption values for the ternary blends are higher than the straight diesel with or without nano additive addition. The specific energy consumption decrease slightly for all the fuel used when the nano additives are added.
Addition of 50 ppm of Al2O3 nano additives enhanced the heat release rate whereas the heat release rate is lesser when the blends are combusted without nano additives considerably. By comparing the ternary blends, it is clear that pentanol ternary blends had the maximum peak pressures. Due to the higher cetane number of biodiesel compared to diesel, the ignition delay was shorter for all blends.
Compared to straight diesel, the biofuel ternary blends in this study recorded high NOX values since the biodiesel blends contains more oxygen content. The ternary blends recorded slightly less CO emissions due to the rich oxygen content which leads to complete oxidation. All the ternary blends recorded higher smoke opacity values. When biodiesel content increases in the blends the smoke opacity also increased. Butanol and propanol recorded higher UHC values.
As per the optimization study, the optimum combination found for all the alcohol ternary blends

Scope for future work

In summary, future research should focus on tackling the present difficulties of NOx emissions of biodiesel operation and nanoparticle durability, while improving mixture concentration and engine operating conditions to get the most out of this potential renewable fuel combination. Varying engine loads and speeds, Injection timing and pressure, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) and Combustion chamber geometry are some of the engine operating conditions can be taken for these fuel samples. The research may be expanded to use quaternary biodiesel mixes in a diesel engine with several cylinders. The chemistry of combustion and atomization may be examined using simulation techniques (CFD). It is possible to assess a simulation process for the performance and combustion of ternary and quaternary biofuel blends in a CI engine. Nanoparticles have the ability to wear down the precise tolerances and critical dimensions of injector orifices and pintels, altering spray patterns and injection timing while also influencing emissions and combustion. To avoid issues like settling and agglomeration, the long-term stability of nanoparticle-enhanced biofuels in storage and use must be thoroughly evaluated.

U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard proposal would mean more vegetable oil imports, high costs, and minimal greenhouse gas reductions

December 16, 2025 | By: Andy Navarrete 

In the last 20 years, the U.S. transportation fuel landscape has transformed: electric vehicles emerged as a clear path to zero-emissions road transport while growth in domestic oil production eliminated U.S. dependence on imported oil. Yet the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS), a 2005 law requiring the use of biofuels in transport, remains stuck in an era when biofuels seemed like the only option to reduce transportation greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and U.S. dependence on foreign oil. The latest proposal from EPA doubles down on this outdated vision. It would raise food and fuel costs for consumers by increasing the amount of biomass-based diesel (BBD) mandated under the program without delivering meaningful GHG emission benefits. 

EPA‚Äôs proposal increases renewable volume obligations (RVOs), the mandatory volumes that specify how much biofuel must be supplied. It also halves the compliance value of imported fuel or fuel produced from imported feedstocks by reducing the generation of renewable identification numbers (RINs)‚Äîcredits used for compliance with renewable fuel blending mandates. For every gallon of biofuel produced from imported feedstock, twice as much fuel must be supplied to meet RFS obligations. Fuels like biodiesel produced from imported used cooking oil now generate half the compliance value of a domestic fuel, such as soy-derived biodiesel.

EPA justifies these changes by emphasizing the economic and energy security benefits of domestic feedstocks. However, overall U.S. consumption of fats and oils for fuel and other purposes such as cooking and animal feed already exceeds total domestic production. Instead of supporting domestic feedstock producers, the proposal would increase U.S. reliance on imported fats and oils.

The figure below shows how growing imports have supported U.S. BBD consumption. In 2019, domestic fat and oil production met 84% of demand. By 2024, this had fallen to 68%. The gap was filled by more imports of vegetable oil, fat oil, and grease. The United States turned from a net exporter of 0.6 million tonnes in 2019 to a net importer of 3.1 million tonnes in 2024.

Figure 1. U.S. fats and oil supplies, 2019 and 2024

EPA‚Äôs proposal would only accelerate this trend, increasing reliance on imported fats, oils, and greases rather than wind them down. The next figure compares EPA‚Äôs projection of the 2027 BBD volumes needed to meet the current proposal with expected domestic fat and oil production and non-fuel consumption. Our projections assume the full utilization of soybean crushing capacity projected by the industry, representing a best-case scenario for domestic vegetable oil supply.

Figure 2. U.S. fats and oil supply and use in 2027 under current proposal

As illustrated by the figure, U.S. fat and oil imports would dramatically increase under the proposal; net vegetable oil imports are projected to surge by around 5 million tonnes (from 6.1 to 11.0 MMT). Greater demand for vegetable oil will increase its price, likely around 12% based on a previous analysis of the relationship between biodiesel demand and global vegetable oil prices. 

However, a more dramatic price spike is possible. As described in EPA‚Äôs Draft Regulatory Impact Assessment, the 2020‚Äì2022 vegetable oil price shock that increased global prices from $700 to $1,800 per metric ton was likely caused by biofuel-driven demand and weather-related supply disruptions. The projected 5 million tonne net increase in U.S. vegetable oil imports is equivalent to 6% of the current global vegetable oil trade, creating a risk of short-term price spikes as global oilseed production responds to the additional demand.

According to EPA analysis, this huge increase in BBD consumption will not even meaningfully reduce U.S. GHG emissions, with savings equivalent to less than 1% of road sector emissions at best. One EPA model even suggests that the use of crop-based BBD fuels would increase GHGs. This is perhaps unsurprising, as current growth in vegetable oil production is concentrated in Brazil and Indonesia, where agricultural expansion often relies on high carbon-stock forested land. Indeed, groundbreaking work from Chen et al. has found that that global demand for BBD between 2002 and 2018 drove the conversion of approximately 1.7 million hectares of forest to oil palm. This means continued market-mediated oil crop expansion could very well offset any emissions reductions from additional BBD use in the United States.

Finally, the proposal‚Äôs claims of energy security benefits are unconvincing. Will energy security really be improved by replacing a domestic energy source (petroleum) with one we have to import? And while EPA assumes that the United States will remain the preferred destination for BBD feedstocks globally, this isn‚Äôt guaranteed. Changing policies in China have dramatically reduced used cooking oil exports to the United States, and sustainable aviation fuel mandates in the European Union and United Kingdom will heighten competition for feedstock.

Overall, EPA projects its current proposal will saddle consumers with $6.8 billion in extra fuel costs and $2.4 billion in higher food prices each year, all without meaningful emissions cuts or improved U.S. energy independence. Twenty years in, we need a wholesale reconsideration of the Renewable Fuel Standard‚Äî the inconsistencies of EPA‚Äôs proposal show exactly why reform is needed.

$2.35 Bn Cooking Oil Recycling Market - Global Forecast 2025-2032: Expansion of Biodiesel Production from Recycled Cooking Oil Boosting Renewable Fuel Supply and Reducing Waste

 The cooking oil recycling market presents opportunities in sustainability and compliance, driven by strict environmental regulations and circular economy trends. Key areas include biofuels, animal feed, and cosmetics, with innovation in processing tech and regional adaptation enhancing supply chain resilience and traceability.

January 13, 2026 04:51 ET | Source: Research and Markets Research and Markets 

---

Dublin, Jan. 13, 2026 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The "Cooking Oil Recycling Market - Global Forecast 2025-2032" has been added to ResearchAndMarkets.com's offering.

The global cooking oil recycling market is forecasted to increase from USD 2.19 billion in 2024 to USD 2.35 billion in 2025, with projected expansion to USD 3.85 billion by 2032 at a compound annual growth rate of 7.32%. 

The cooking oil recycling market plays a central role in advancing supply chain sustainability, regulatory compliance, and operational efficiency. Senior decision-makers increasingly turn to these solutions as expectations for traceable sourcing and responsible industry practices rise across global sectors.

This upward trend is shaped by stricter environmental regulations, ongoing improvements in oil refinement and purification technology, and escalating focus on circular economy adoption. Many leading organizations incorporate recycled oil into operations, advancing both sustainability objectives and compliance standards through alternative fuel integration and enhanced supply chain traceability.

Key Takeaways and Strategic Insights: Cooking Oil Recycling Market

Recycled cooking oil solutions offer increased agility and resilience for sectors including agriculture, energy, and consumer-facing businesses seeking to address evolving regulatory challenges.
Processing technology innovation expands feedstock options, enabling companies to access a wider supplier network and optimize sourcing flexibility.
Cross-sector partnerships, from foodservice to logistics and oil recovery, foster more efficient resource collection, enable traceability, and reduce risks related to contamination or operational disruption.
Regional business adaptation allows organizations to adjust operational practices for specific regulatory environments and maintain compliance with evolving legal frameworks.
Integrated sourcing and logistics strategies stabilize input quality and costs while limiting vulnerability to marketplace volatility or geopolitical shifts.
Deployment of digital purification systems combined with real-time monitoring tools supports transparency and enhances traceability mandates in sustainable supply chain management.

Scope & Segmentation

Application:

Animal feed manufacturers use recycled oil to improve nutritional compounds.
Biofuel producers rely on it for alternative fuel processing.
Cosmetics companies incorporate recycled input to ensure consistent product quality.
Energy and chemical industries seek efficiency gains and superior resource utilization when sourcing these materials.

Feedstock:

Animal byproduct tallow addresses targeted industrial requirements.
Vegetable oils such as soybean and rapeseed offer availability for volume applications.
Waste oils sourced from restaurants and food processors strengthen circular supply networks and validate sustainability initiatives.

Process:

Hydrodeoxygenation, pyrolysis, and transesterification serve as core conversion processes.
These technologies enable the upcycling of waste oils into renewable fuels and raw materials, delivering operational adaptability for business needs and current regulatory demands.

Region:

The Americas, including the United States, Canada, Brazil, and Mexico, present varying maturity levels.
Europe, Middle East, and Africa (e.g., UK, France, Germany, UAE, South Africa), along with Asia-Pacific economies such as China, India, Japan, Australia, South Korea, and Singapore, exhibit distinct supply chain and compliance dynamics, presenting both challenges and opportunities for market expansion.

Why This Report Matters

Enables organizations to refine supply chain and procurement strategies in the cooking oil recycling market by anticipating change and proactively responding to evolving dynamics.
Benchmarks best-practice methods for technology adoption and compliance, supporting efficient decision-making amid regulatory change.
Reveals collaboration opportunities and infrastructure priorities to assist companies in advancing circular economy efforts and ensuring operational resilience across diverse regional markets.

Conclusion

Sustained advantage in the cooking oil recycling market requires strong supply networks, robust traceability, and active cross-sector collaboration. Adopting these approaches positions organizations to address changing regulatory conditions and industry demands effectively.

Key Topics Covered:

Enhancing diesel engine efficiency with waste cooking oil biodiesel and nano additives for sustainable fuel applications

Haiter Lenin Allasi ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-4212-91631,5,
Amala Justus Selvam2,
Mary Vasanthi Soosaimariyan3 &
‚Ä¶
Sujin Jose Arul4
Show authors 

Scientific Reports volume 15, Article number: 31762 (2025)Cite this article 

2743 Accesses
5 Citations
Metrics details

 Subjects

Energy science and technology
Environmental sciences

Abstract

This study investigates the effect of incorporating nano-additives Cerium oxide (CeO2), Zinc oxide (ZnO), and Titanium oxide (TiO2) at 25 ppm concentration into biodiesel derived from waste cooking oil, with the objective of improving diesel engine performance and reducing exhaust emissions. Experiments were carried out on a single-cylinder four-stroke diesel engine under varying load conditions. Among the tested blends, the B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) mixture exhibited a modest reduction in brake thermal efficiency (2.53%) and a slight increase in brake specific energy consumption (3.80%) compared to diesel fuel. However, significant emission improvements were achieved, with a reduction in CO (23.42%) and HC (24.78%) emissions, accompanied by a decrease in smoke opacity (12.37%). The findings highlight that TiO2 nano-additive biodiesel blends offer a sustainable and environmentally viable alternative to conventional diesel. The study is constrained by its emphasis on a particular mixture of biodiesel and nano additives, perhaps limiting the generalisability to different combinations or concentrations. The study largely assesses engine performance and emissions under a singular operating condition, potentially neglecting differences in performance across varied loads or speeds.

The utilisation of petroleum diesel fuel derived from fossil fuels faces two significant challenges: the first challenge is a scarcity of available sources, and the second challenge is the detrimental impact on the natural environment. Biodiesel has garnered considerable acclaim as an environmentally friendly fuel and has become one of the leading alternatives to traditional petroleum-based diesel. Biodiesel is generated through the fermentation of vegetable oils, as opposed to the combustion of fossil fuels. The generation of biodiesel, which can be derived from animal fats, used cooking oil, and oil extracted from microalgae, necessitates the incorporation of long-chain fatty acids as a fundamental input material. It comes from both consumable and non-consumable sources, including rapeseed oil, coconut oil, sunflower oil, soybean oil, groundnut oil, and palm oil. Examples of non-edible oil resources include mahua, castor, cotton, rubber, animal tallow, neem, jatropha, and jojoba. Additional examples encompass mahua, sunflower oil, soybean oil, rapeseed oil, palm oil, coconut oil, and groundnut oil, all of which serve as sources of edible oils[3](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR3 "Bouguessa, R., Tarabet, L., Loubar, K., Belmrabet, T. & Tazerout, M. This study examined the performance and emission characteristics of biodiesel made from waste cooking oil in diesel engines that were combined with nano additives of cerium, zinc, and titanium oxide.

Addition of zinc oxide (ZnO) to biodiesel acts as a catalyst and it reduces the time and temperature required for complete combustion and thereby decreases the ignition delay which results in the increase in cetane number. Cerium oxide (CeO2) has the ability to store and release oxygen. When cerium oxide is mixed with biodiesel and heated, it releases oxygen. Increase in oxygen amount facilitates quick and complete combustion. This increases the fuel efficiency. It also helps to reduce the harmful emission of carbon monoxide and smoke. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanoparticles act as a catalyst and it increases the speed of oxidation and it helps in complete combustion. This approach is novel because it identifies as a sustainable alternative for conventional diesel fuel: enhanced with nanoparticles, biodiesel generated from waste cooking oil. The work integrates ultrasonic insertion of nano additives (cerium, zinc, and titanium oxide), transesterification with a lipase-enhanced nano catalyst. The study presents an absolute evaluation of performance, emission of an engine with B20 fuel and TiO2 nano additive and conclusively positively identifies the outcomes as sustainable fuel alternative for conventional fossil fuel in a prime mover.

Using waste cooking oil biodiesel mixed with nano-additives (cerium, zinc, and titanium oxide) by ultrasonic treatment seeks to improve diesel engine efficiency. According to the theory, these combinations will lower hazardous emissions and increase engine performance relative to standard diesel. The effects of these combinations on brake thermal efficiency, brake specific energy consumption, and emissions at a constant engine speed of 1500 rpm are assessed in this work. Supporting their possible use as a sustainable fuel alternative, results demonstrate that the B20 + TiO2 mix displays encouraging decreases in unburned hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide, and smoke emissions.

Although numerous studies have explored the integration of nano additives in biodiesel to improve engine performance and reduce emissions, the present study distinguishes itself through several innovative aspects. The use of nano-additives to enhance combustion, heat transfer, and emission reduction. Nano-metal oxides such as CeO2, ZnO, and TiO2 have shown catalytic properties that promote better atomization, reduce ignition delay, and improve oxidation of unburnt hydrocarbons. This study focuses on evaluating the performance and emission characteristics of WCO biodiesel blended with 25 ppm concentrations of CeO2, ZnO, and TiO2 nanoparticles in a compression ignition engine. The novelty of this work lies in the comparative assessment of different nano-additives in waste cooking oil biodiesel and their practical implications for improving sustainability in diesel engine operations. The study evaluates engine performance and emissions comprehensively using these blends in a standard diesel engine without modifications, thus emphasizing real-world feasibility. From a techno-economic standpoint, the low additive concentration combined with substantial gains in combustion efficiency and emission reduction positions this approach as a promising and scalable alternative to conventional diesel.

Materials and methods

Waste cooking oil was converted to biodiesel by transesterification process with the help of lipase immobilized with Fe3O4 catalyst. This catalyst possesses a few advantageous properties, such as being reusable, non-toxic, immune to the effects of free fatty acids found in seed oils, an organic solvent, and an enhancement of the biodiesel production process. Initially, the necessary amount of lipase immobilised nano catalyst was placed in an airtight glass bottle (550 millilitres) and combined with raw waste cooking (250 millilitres), Fe3O4 nano catalyst (1%), while being stirred by a pellet in a magnetic stirrer at a speed ranging from 850 to 1200 rpm. This reaction was started at a temperature of 20 degrees Celsius with a period of 12 min; this parameter was maintained with the operation of a magnetic stirrer, and then the complete procedure was carried out in a closed environment. During this process of transesterification, the lipase immobilised in Fe3O4 nano catalyst works to drive the reaction and continually break the chain of triglycerides that are present in raw waste cooking oil. At the end of this process, the required quantity of Fatty Acid Methyl Ester (FAME) of raw waste cooking oil was successfully extracted with minimal glycerol, which improves the total yield of the reaction.

 Fuel preparation

Initially, the required amount of lipase-immobilized Fe3O4 nano catalyst was placed in an airtight 550-milliliter glass bottle and combined with 250 millilitres of raw waste cooking oil and 1% Fe3O4 nano catalyst. The mixture was stirred using a magnetic stirrer with a pellet at a speed of 850 to 1200 rpm. Initiated at 20 ¬∞C, the reaction was kept in a sealed condition for twelve minutes. The immobilized lipase Fe3O4 nano catalyst helped the waste cooking oil triglycerides to be continuously hydrolysed, thus ensuring effective conversion into biodiesel during the transesterification process. Ultrasonication process

To ensure homogeneous dispersion of nano additives into the B20 biodiesel blend, ultrasonication was performed using a probe-type ultrasonic processor was carried out using a PCI Ultrasonics Model ULTRAMAX-9 L, equipped with a titanium alloy probe of 12 mm diameter, operating at a frequency of 20 kHz and a power of 500 W for 30 min. The selection of a 25ppm concentration for all nano additives was based on prior literature reports[1](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7ref-CR1 "Agarwal, S., Kumari, S., Mudgal, A. & Khan, S. Green synthesized nanoadditives in Jojoba biodiesel-diesel blends: an improvement of engine performance and emission. Renew. Energy. 147, 1836‚Äì1844. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2019.09.139

 (2020)."), which suggested that nano additive concentrations in the range of 20‚Äì30 ppm optimize combustion characteristics while preventing nanoparticle agglomeration. Preliminary experiments in this study also validated that 25 ppm provided stable dispersion and notable improvements in engine performance.

Lipase-immobilized Fe3O4 nano catalyst

The lipase-immobilized Fe3O4 nano catalyst, procured from Anna University, was employed for the transesterification process. Immobilization of lipase on magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles enhances enzymatic stability, reusability, and catalytic efficiency, facilitating effective biodiesel production from waste cooking oil. The synthesis involves co-precipitation of Fe¬≥‚Å∫ and Fe¬≤‚Å∫ salts, functionalization for enzyme attachment, and subsequent lipase immobilization to ensure catalytic activity and reusability. The MNPs of Fe3O4 are first synthesized by co-precipitation of Fe¬≥‚Å∫ and Fe¬≤‚Å∫ salts in alkaline solution followed by washing and drying to obtain a stable nanostructure. For enhanced enzyme immobilisation, the Fe3O4 MNPs are functionalised with 3-amino propyltriethoxysilane (APTES) or glutaraldehyde to ensure reactive sites are formed for enzyme bonding as shown in Fig. 2. The functionalised nanoparticles are then incubated using lipase enzymes in a phosphate buffer solution to allow adsorption or covalent binding, with crosslinking possible using glutaraldehyde for enhanced stability.

The Fe3O4 lipase nano catalyst that is immobilized with lipase is identified using different techniques, such as Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM), in an attempt to validate its structural stability, enzyme immobilization, and magnetic characteristics.  GC analysis of biodiesel synthesized from waste cooking oil

This investigation employed precise analytical techniques to determine the fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) profile of waste cooking oil biodiesel. Quantitative analysis was performed using the Turbo Mass Version 5.4.2 software, and gas chromatography (GC) was selected as the primary technique due to its high sensitivity and resolution for FAME detection. The analysis was carried out using an Agilent GC 6890 N system, equipped with a Flame Ionization Detector (FID) and a capillary column HP-88 (30 m √ó 0.25 mm ID √ó 0.20 Œºm film thickness), and specifically designed for FAME profiling.

The GC oven temperature program was set as follows: initial temperature of 120 ¬∞C (held for 2 min), ramped at 10 ¬∞C/min to 180 ¬∞C (held for 1 min), and followed by an increase of 3 ¬∞C/min to 240 ¬∞C (held for 10 min). The injector and detector (FID) temperatures were maintained at 260 ¬∞C and 280 ¬∞C, respectively. The carrier gas used was hydrogen, delivered at a constant flow rate of 1.0 mL/min, with a split ratio of 50:1 to ensure optimal resolution. Prior to injection, the acid value was determined using 0.1 N alcoholic phenolphthalein indicator, ensuring the oil‚Äôs suitability for methyl ester conversion. Figure 3 (A) presents the GC chromatogram of the extracted FAMEs from waste cooking oil biodiesel. The major components identified included methyl palmitate (\~ 35%), methyl oleate (\~ 30%), and methyl linoleate (\~ 20%), which are known to enhance cetane number and improve combustion characteristics in biodiesel applications.

FTIR analysis of raw waste cooking oil and biodiesel

The FTIR analysis was conducted to verify the transesterification process of waste cooking oil into biodiesel by confirming the disappearance of triglyceride groups and the appearance of ester functional groups, which indicates successful biodiesel formation. The FTIR instrument was employed to analyse the extracted waste cooking oil biodiesel sample for the purpose of this investigation. An omnic software version was utilised for the analysis. The investigation was carried out using a Magna 750 FTIR spectrometer that was outfitted with a Deuterated Triglycine sulphate detector. Additionally, a 7.3 KBr splitter and a Ni Chrome source were used in the process. After determining that the range between 500 and 4000 was appropriate, a resolution of 2 was applied to the FTIR spectrum that can be seen in Fig. 3(B). About 3000‚Äì2800 is the important spectrum range that generates chemical inequality between raw oil and waste cooking oil biodiesel. This area is referred to as the fingerprint region.

The steep peaks that may be seen in the range between 3003 and 2850 correspond to an aliphatic CH of a hybridised alkene, as well as a sp2-CH and sp3-CH stretch. In addition, the 1737 frequency peak that corresponds to the stretching of the keto group is associated with the ester. In a similar vein, the stretch in area 1627 substantiates the existence of an unsaturated double bond and does not combine with a keto group. A peak band of 3003, followed by a peak band of 2850, provides the stretching of the methyl ester group. The various spectrum bands were differentiated by a stronger band between 3000 and 2800\. In the spectrum range of raw oil, the peak at 1469 was seen, and methylene groups are deserving of credit for producing it. The various characteristic peaks that were observed in the FTIR spectrum of raw waste cooking oil biodiesel was as follows: olefin group (c = c) at 1627, alkene C-H (Aliphatic) (sp2-CH) was presented at 3003, carbonyl single bond to the ester (O-C = O) was observed at 1731, and lastly, an alkane C-H (sp3-CH) component was shown at 2850\. The existence of saturated fatty acids, a carbohydrate chain, and a -C = O stretch may be deduced from the appropriate absorbance peak for waste cooking oil biodiesel, which is located at 1721\. (esters and acids). An amide group could be the source of the 1570 peaks in the spectrum caused by the waste cooking oil biodiesel extract. Last but not least, an increased peak at 1321 was seen in the retrieved waste cooking oil biodiesel spectra, and it was shown to be connected to the glycerol group (O-CH3). Significant peaks were identified: 1737 cm‚Åª¬π (carbonyl group stretch indicating ester formation), 1469 cm‚Åª¬π (methylene group vibration), 1570 cm‚Åª¬π (amide group), 3003 cm‚Åª¬π and 2850 cm‚Åª¬π (sp¬≤-CH and sp¬≥-CH stretches), confirming successful transesterification of waste cooking oil into biodiesel.

 Characterization of cerium, zinc and titanium oxide nano additives

The CeO2, ZnO, and TiO2 nanoparticles used in this work were purchased from a certified commercial supplier to ensure consistency and reproducibility of particle size and quality. SEM analysis was performed to study the surface morphology and agglomeration of the nanoparticles, as these characteristics strongly affect combustion behaviour and catalytic activity when blended with biodiesel. Figure 4 (A, B, C) presents the SEM images showing the morphology of Cerium Oxide, Titanium Oxide, and Zinc Oxide nanoparticles, respectively, with an observed particle size range of 40‚Äì80 nm. SEM analysis was conducted to characterize the surface morphology and particle distribution of the synthesised nano additives. The samples were gold-coated using a sputter coater to enhance conductivity and reduce charging effects. SEM imaging was performed using a VEGA3 TESCAN scanning electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 35 kV. The analysis was conducted under high vacuum conditions (approximately 0.02 torr) to improve image resolution. The secondary electron (SE) detector was used to capture surface topography, with a working distance maintained at 10‚Äì15 mm, optimized for depth of field and image sharpness.

The results indicated a uniform distribution of nanoparticles with moderate agglomeration, which is typical of powders synthesized via the sol-gel combustion method. The morphology revealed semi-spherical particles with distinct porous structures, contributing to the formation of nanoscale voids and a larger surface area, which is favourable for additive applications. In pursuit of attaining the desired premium diesel output, this study investigated the performance and emission characteristics of waste cooking oil biodiesel fuel blends with nano additives, without introducing any modifications to the diesel engine. Technoeconomic perspective

The cost of raw waste cooking oil is economically favourable compared to that of virgin oils. Titanium dioxide (TiO‚ÇÇ), used as a nano additive at a low dosage of 25 ppm, is widely available and cost-effective, with its cost remaining marginal when distributed across the total fuel volume. Although ultrasonication requires an initial capital investment, it significantly enhances additive dispersion and fuel stability, thereby reducing maintenance demands and operational issues. Moreover, the reduction in emissions such as CO, HC, and particulate matter (PM) can help lower expenses associated with after-treatment systems and potential carbon penalties[18](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7ref-CR18 "Kalargaris, I. et al.  (2017).").

Our study systematically compares the influence of three individual nano-oxides (TiO‚ÇÇ, ZnO, CeO‚ÇÇ) at a controlled 25 ppm concentration using ultrasonication for dispersion. Most existing studies either focus on a single nano additive or use higher, non-standardized concentrations, often without dispersion stability assurance.

Stability of the fuels

The stability of biodiesel blends containing nanoparticles is critical to ensure consistent combustion performance, injector safety, and long-term storage feasibility. In this study, a qualitative stability evaluation was performed for B20 blends incorporated with TiO‚ÇÇ, CeO‚ÇÇ, and ZnO at 25 ppm concentration using ultrasonication for 30 min at 40 kHz frequency to ensure homogeneous dispersion. Each fuel sample was stored in transparent glass containers at ambient room temperature (‚âà 25 ¬∞C) for a duration of 30 days, without agitation. The samples were visually inspected at intervals of 1, 7, 15, and 30 days to check for Sediment formation at the bottom, Color changes, Phase separation, Hazy or cloudy appearance.

Observations TiO‚ÇÇ-blended B20 remained visually stable with no visible sedimentation or separation for up to 30 days. ZnO and CeO‚ÇÇ blends showed slight cloudiness and minimal sediment formation after 15 days, indicating potential early-stage agglomeration. All blends retained color uniformity, suggesting no major phase instability.

 Experimental details

Figure 5 shows the experimental set up for the experimentation. The work was carried out using a Kirloskar single-cylinder diesel engine. Operating at 1500 revolutions per minute, this engine produced 5.2 kW. The injection timing was set at 23¬∞ before top dead centre (BTDC), and the injection pressure was maintained at 210 bar throughout the experiments. The important instruments were connected to or permanently attached to the diesel engine so that all of the research tests could be carried out. By adjusting the engine load while keeping the speed constant, we were able to approximate the outcomes of these tests. In the first phase, the diesel engine was run on its standard premium diesel fuel to establish a baseline for the full load scenario and to account for the parameters that were wanted. All the diesel fuel blends tested in this study premium diesel, waste cooking oil biodiesel, and the blends with nano additives were run in the engine without any modifications to achieve the specified output.

The single-cylinder diesel engine (TAF-1) type produced by the Kirloskar brand was used for this in-depth experimental study work. The different diesel engine specifications are summarized in Table 2. A data capture system‚Äôs software helped record the combustion parameters of this diesel engine on a personal computer after coupling it with an eddy current dynamometer. Next, a purpose-built software application was used to estimate and analyse the combustion properties of this engine. Located adjacent to the gasoline tank, the fuel control unit was equipped with a pressure sensor that senses the pressure of the engine‚Äôs fuel intake. The sensor is a piezoelectric pressure transducer 7063-A type linked with a Kistler instrument. We did this to make the engine run more smoothly. The analyser, encoder, and amplifier were manufactured by the Swiss company Kistler AG to distinguish the different engine input signals.

The engine speed of 1500 rpm was set using a connection between the flywheel, an optical sensor, and a K-type thermocouple. Monitoring exhaust gas temperature was achieved with another K-type thermocouple, while pollutant emissions underwent analysis with the AVL five-gas analyser (AVL444). Specifically, the engine was allowed to run for 20‚Äì25 min at each load condition to reach thermal equilibrium. Steady-state was confirmed by monitoring key parameters such as exhaust gas temperature, coolant temperature, lubricating oil temperature, and fuel consumption rate. Data acquisition was initiated only after these parameters remained consistent over a period of time, indicating that the engine had reached a stable operating condition. Following a 20‚Äì25 min run on premium diesel to release pollutants, SAE 40 lubricating oil was introduced to enhance the diesel engine‚Äôs efficiency. Pollutant emissions were then directed to a nondispersive infrared sensor for analysis, with smoke detected by an electrochemical sensor and NOx emissions monitored by the AVL 437 C type instrument. The diesel engine‚Äôs stopping capability was assessed at 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100% of the input load. The temperature of the ambient air is 32 ¬∞C and the humidity of the lab is 74% when experiment was performed under laboratory conditions. The HRR was derived from in-cylinder pressure data using a first-law thermodynamic approach, assuming a single-zone combustion model and incorporating volume variation with crank angle. This model assumes the combustion chamber as a homogeneous zone with uniform thermodynamic properties, which significantly simplifies the calculations while still providing meaningful insights into combustion characteristics.

The justification for this choice lies in its wide acceptance in preliminary combustion analysis, especially for single-cylinder engines like the Kirloskar diesel engine used in our work. It enables the estimation of global combustion trends such as ignition delay, combustion duration, and HRR profile with reasonable accuracy.

However, we acknowledge the limitations of the single-zone model. It does not account for spatial variations in temperature, pressure, or fuel-air equivalence ratio, and it ignores effects such as crevice flows, heat losses to cylinder walls, and stratification. While more advanced multi-zone or CFD models can address these complexities, they require detailed input parameters and significantly higher computational resources.

Uncertainty and repeatability

The maximum tolerable deviation measures the precision of an instrument, which defines how much a quantity measured can be different from the actual or true quantity. In fact, considering variables such as the range of the instrument and extraneous variables, uncertainty is the interval within which the true result will probably fall. For example, the AVL 437 smoke meter has an accuracy of 1%, meaning that its measurement can be off by up to 1% from the actual value. Its uncertainty is also 1%, which is the measurement‚Äôs confidence interval. Similarly, the AVL GH14d pressure transducer has an accuracy of 0.1 bar and an uncertainty of 0.15%, which ensures reliable pressure measurements. The precision and reliability of the experimental results were assessed through a detailed uncertainty analysis. Measurement uncertainties were calculated by considering both instrumental errors and procedural variabilities. For calculated performance parameters like Brake Thermal Efficiency (BTE) and Brake Specific Energy Consumption (BSEC), the total uncertainty (U\_total) was obtained using the root-sum-square (RSS) method.

$$\\:\\text{U}\\:\\text{t}\\text{o}\\text{t}\\text{a}\\text{l}\\:=\\sqrt{{U}\{1}^{2}+{U}\{2}^{2}+\\dots\\:.+{U}\_{n}^{2}}$$

Where, U1, U2, U3‚Ä¶ Un are the individual uncertainties from contributing parameters. In addition, the reproducibility of measurements has been guaranteed by repeating every test three times to enhance the reliability and lower experimental errors. Considering instrument precision and repeatability, the uncertainty in Brake Thermal Efficiency (BTE) and Brake Specific Energy Consumption (BSEC) measurements was ¬± 2.5%. Emission measurements (CO, UBHC, NOx) were within ¬± 3% uncertainty.

 Results and discussion

Performance characteristics of waste cooking oil biodiesel with nano additives

Figure 6A and B present the brake thermal efficiency (BTE) and brake specific energy consumption (BSEC) for the various fuel blends tested. The addition of nano-additives significantly influences the combustion characteristics of biodiesel blends, contributing to improved BTE and reduced BSEC. Among the tested blends, B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) exhibited the most favourable performance, recording a BTE of 31.21%, which is only 2.53% lower than premium diesel (32%) and 6.05% higher than regular B20 (29.32%). This enhanced performance is attributed to the catalytic nature of TiO2, which facilitates oxidation reactions through oxygen release and surface interaction. Its high surface area improves fuel atomization and evaporation, ensuring more uniform air-fuel mixing and efficient combustion. The presence of TiO2 also reduces ignition delay and enhances in-cylinder pressure rise, leading to improved thermal energy conversion. In terms of BSEC, B20 + TiO2 recorded a value of 12.08 MJ/kW.hr, showing only a 3.80% increase compared to premium diesel (11.62 MJ/kW.hr). This is significantly better than B20 without additives (13.37 MJ/kW.hr) and B100 (highest BSEC). The reduction in BSEC despite biodiesel‚Äôs inherently lower calorific value and higher viscosity is due to the improved combustion efficiency facilitated by TiO2. The additive‚Äôs thermal conductivity and catalytic action reduce energy losses and promote complete combustion, leading to better fuel utilization. Overall, TiO2 outperformed CeO2 and ZnO, which recorded lower BTE and higher BSEC values. This suggests that TiO2 is the most effective among the tested additives in enhancing engine performance using biodiesel blends.

The maximum brake thermal efficiency was recorded for premium diesel at 32%, and second to this was B20 blended with TiO2 (25 ppm) at 31.21%. This is a drop of 2.53% compared to diesel and an increase of 6.05% over regular B20\. The CeO2 and ZnO blends exhibited a slightly lower BTE of 30.08% and 30.01%, respectively, while B20 without any nano-additives exhibited a BTE of 29.32%. The poorest efficiency was obtained with B100 at 26.9%, which was caused by its high viscosity, low calorific value, and poor volatility, resulting in incomplete combustion and excessive energy losses. The BSEC was the lowest for the high diesel at 11.62 MJ/kW.hr, followed by a value of 12.08 MJ/kW.hr for the B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) blend, indicating a modest rise of merely 3.80%. The CeO2\-ZnO mixtures recorded slightly higher BSEC values of 12.21 MJ/kW.hr and 12.51 MJ/kW.hr, respectively, whereas B20 was 13.37 MJ/kW.hr, indicating the higher energy demand for biodiesel blends without nano-additives. The study indicates the feasibility of adopting nano-additive-doped biodiesel as a substitute fuel, highlighted on its ability to improve efficiency and reduce environmental footprints with little need for adapting traditional engine systems. While our study notes a slight reduction in BTE (2.53%) and increase in NOX (8.58%) with B20 + TiO2, it also reports significant reductions in UBHC, CO, and smoke emissions, showing improved combustion and cleaner exhaust.

Combustion characteristics of waste cooking oil biodiesel with nano additives

Figure 7(A) shows the in-cylinder pressure variation with crank angle, while Fig. 7(B) presents the corresponding heat release rate (HRR). Premium diesel recorded the highest in-cylinder pressure at 59.86 bar, followed by B20 + TiO2 (58.82 bar), B20 + CeO2 (57.21 bar), and B20 + ZnO (57.21 bar). B20 without additives and B100 recorded 56.97 bar and 54.48 bar, respectively. The near-maximum cylinder pressure observed for B20 + TiO2 reflects better combustion stability due to improved atomization and oxygen diffusion promoted by the additive.

The enhanced combustion process is driven by TiO2‚Äôs high thermal conductivity and oxygen buffering capability. These properties promote quicker and more complete combustion, resulting in shorter ignition delay and more stable combustion phasing. The nano-additive‚Äôs surface catalysis supports fuel breakdown and oxidation, contributing to elevated in-cylinder pressures with minimal energy loss. The HRR values presented in Fig. 7(B) show a maximum of 71.71 J/¬∞CA for premium diesel, followed by 66.65 J/¬∞CA for B20 + TiO2, and progressively lower values for CeO2, ZnO, and B20\. B100 recorded the lowest HRR. The 7.59% reduction in HRR for B20 + TiO2, compared to diesel, reflects the change in combustion dynamics due to the nano-additive. Despite a lower peak HRR, the broader and smoother release curve indicates more stable and prolonged combustion, which is beneficial for reducing knocking and improving fuel efficiency. In summary, the combustion analysis confirms that TiO2 promotes more efficient combustion through improved atomization, oxygen diffusion, and catalytic effects, helping biodiesel blends to approach the performance of premium diesel.
