The observed improvements in combustion and emission characteristics with nano-additive biodiesel blends can be attributed to the catalytic and oxygen-supplying roles of the nanoparticles. TiO2 nanoparticles act as oxygen donors, releasing oxygen radicals at elevated temperatures and thereby promoting the complete oxidation of CO to CO‚ÇÇ and HC to CO2 and H2O. CeO2 nanoparticles participate in a reversible Ce¬≥‚Å∫/Ce‚Å¥‚Å∫ redox cycle, functioning as an oxygen buffer that stores and releases oxygen during combustion, which shortens ignition delay and improves combustion completeness.

$$\\text{CeO}\{2} \\leftrightarrow \\text{Ce}\{2}\\text{O}\{3} + 1/2 \\,\\text{O}\2$$

ZnO nanoparticles, on the other hand, act as catalysts by lowering the activation energy of oxidation reactions, enhancing fuel‚Äìair mixing, and facilitating faster combustion. Collectively, these mechanisms explain the reduction in CO, HC, and smoke emissions, along with the improvements in thermal efficiency observed in this study.

Cylinder pressure and heat release rate (HRR) analysis revealed a 1.76% reduction in peak pressure and a 7.59% decrease in HRR for the TiO2 blend. These changes are linked to delayed ignition and enhanced atomization caused by the nano additive‚Äôs oxygen buffering capacity, which promotes smoother combustion and reduces knocking tendency23 blends operated in a single cylinder diesel engine: performance, combustion and emission characteristics. Energy 215, 119091 (2021).").

Emission characteristics of waste cooking oil biodiesel with nano additives

Emission measurements, including unburned hydrocarbons (UBHC), carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NOx), and smoke, were recorded and analyzed with respect to brake power (Fig. 8A&B and 9A&B). B20 + TiO2 consistently showed the best emission performance among the biodiesel blends. UBHC emissions were reduced by 17.41% with B20 + TiO2 compared to premium diesel, due to enhanced oxidation and complete combustion. The TiO2 additive helps maintain optimal in-cylinder temperatures and prevents quenching effects near the cylinder wall, thereby minimizing hydrocarbon residues. Its catalytic activity promotes degradation of unburned hydrocarbon chains, ensuring minimal UBHC in the exhaust. CO emissions showed a 36.36% reduction with B20 + TiO2. This is due to the high oxygen content and improved oxidation efficiency of the blend, which promotes full conversion of CO to CO2 during combustion. TiO2‚Äôs role in reducing ignition delay and improving combustion phasing further ensures lower CO formation. NOx emissions, however, increased by 8.58% with B20 + TiO2, a typical trend in biodiesel combustion due to higher in-cylinder temperatures and increased oxygen availability. Nonetheless, TiO2 produced the lowest NOx among the nano-additive blends. This is attributed to its oxygen buffering capability, which helps regulate combustion temperature and limits localized hot spots. The nanoparticle also aids in more uniform heat distribution, partially mitigating NOx formation. Smoke emissions were reduced by 16.25% with B20 + TiO2 compared to diesel. TiO2 acts as a combustion enhancer, promoting complete oxidation of carbonaceous compounds and reducing soot formation. Improved atomization and fuel-air mixing further contribute to this effect. In summary, TiO2 significantly improves emission performance by lowering UBHC, CO, and smoke emissions while moderately increasing NOx, which can be managed by incorporating exhaust after-treatment technologies such as EGR or SCR systems in future studies. The behavior is said to increase as the percentage of the fuel blend grew, in addition to greater smoke emissions, especially at full load condition. It was, however, noted that the premium diesel recorded maximum smoke emissions when compared to all the biodiesel fuel blends. The smoke emission levels for different fuel blends were 78.4 HSU for premium diesel, 67.44 HSU for B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm), 68.54 HSU for B20 + CeO2 (25 ppm), 68.5 HSU for B20 + ZnO (25 ppm), 71.85 HSU for B20, and 68.8 HSU for B100\. Among these, the B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) mixture showed an enormous reduction of 16.25% in smoke emissions in comparison to premium diesel under load conditions. The phase of diffusion burning is also improved to prevent the possibility of sooting and providing improved air-fuel mixing to inhibit local zones of fuel enrichment, which characteristically form locations of partial burning. The greater thermal conductivity of TiO2 also promotes more even distribution of heat and prevents local cooling, which reduces temperature drops contributing to soot. These complementary effects are credited with the noticed reduction in emissions of smoke that render B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) less harmful to the environment compared to regular diesel fuel and other blends of nano-additives[31](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR31 "Rami Reddy, S., Murali, G. & Dhana Raju, V. Assessment of diethyl ether as a fuel additive on the diverse characteristics of diesel engine powered with waste Mango seed biodiesel blend. Int. J. Ambient Energy. 43, 3365‚Äì3376. 
 https://doi.org/10.1080/01430750.2020.1824944

 (2022).").

The economic feasibility and scalability of employing nano additives in biodiesel engines remain critical considerations for real-world implementation. Although small quantities (typically 25‚Äì100 ppm) of nanoparticles can yield notable improvements in engine performance and emission reduction, the cost of nanoparticle production, particularly for materials like cerium oxide or zinc oxide, can be relatively high compared to conventional additives32, 2560‚Äì2577. 
 https://doi.org/10.1080/15567036.2020.1754604

 (2021).").

In addition, the synthesis methods often involving chemical precipitation, sol-gel, or hydrothermal processes may require controlled environments and energy inputs, raising concerns about production scalability for industrial applications. Efforts to develop green and cost-effective synthesis techniques using plant extracts or waste materials are ongoing and may offer a more viable route for large-scale deployment[33](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR33 "Barathiraja, C. et al. Green synthesis of cerium oxide nanoparticles using Moringa Oleifera leaf extract and their application in biodiesel blends. Fuel 279, 118518. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fuel.2020.118518

 (2020)."),34, 6557‚Äì6561. 
 https://doi.org/10.1021/es101792z

 (2010).").

From an environmental standpoint, the lifecycle impact of nanoparticles must be carefully evaluated. While nano additives demonstrate technical benefits, cost optimization, green synthesis methods, and comprehensive environmental assessments are crucial for their large-scale, economically feasible, and environmentally responsible application in biodiesel-fuelled engines[35](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR35 "Sajjad, W. et al. A comprehensive review on the performance of diesel engine using biodiesel and nano-additives. Energy Rep. 6, 3856‚Äì3886. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyr.2020.10.057

 (2020).").

The present study observed an improvement in BTE and a reduction in emissions such as CO, UBHC, and NOx upon the addition of nano additives (e.g., cerium oxide, titanium oxide) to biodiesel blends. These findings are generally consistent with previous studies. For instance, Sajjad et al.[35](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR35 "Sajjad, W. et al. A comprehensive review on the performance of diesel engine using biodiesel and nano-additives. Energy Rep. 6, 3856‚Äì3886. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyr.2020.10.057

 (2020).") and Singh et al.32, 2560‚Äì2577. 
 https://doi.org/10.1080/15567036.2020.1754604

 (2021).") reported enhanced BTE and decreased emission levels when CeO‚ÇÇ and ZnO nanoparticles were added to biodiesel, attributing this to improved oxygen availability and catalytic oxidation during combustion.

However, a slight discrepancy was noted in the extent of NOx reduction. While our study showed a moderate decrease in NOx emissions with nano additive use, Barathiraja et al.[33](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR33 "Barathiraja, C. et al. Green synthesis of cerium oxide nanoparticles using Moringa Oleifera leaf extract and their application in biodiesel blends. Fuel 279, 118518. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fuel.2020.118518

 (2020).") reported a more significant reduction under similar conditions. This difference could stem from variations in nanoparticle concentration, base fuel properties, or engine operating conditions. In our case, the NOx reduction may have been limited due to higher in-cylinder temperatures associated with enhanced combustion, which can offset the NOx suppression effect of oxygenated fuels.

The emission trends also align with findings from Sajjad et al.[35](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR35 "Sajjad, W. et al. A comprehensive review on the performance of diesel engine using biodiesel and nano-additives. Energy Rep. 6, 3856‚Äì3886. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyr.2020.10.057

 (2020)."), where CO and HC emissions decreased due to better oxidation, but the magnitude of reduction varied. This could be influenced by the nanoparticle size, dispersion method (ultrasonication vs. mechanical stirring), and engine load condition.

The only adverse effect was an 8.58% increase in NO‚Çì emissions, which is consistent with biodiesel‚Äôs inherent oxygen content and elevated combustion temperature. However, the increase in NO‚Çì was lower with TiO‚ÇÇ than with CeO2 and ZnO due to TiO2‚Äôs oxygen-buffering ability, which tempers the peak flame temperatures.

This is in agreement with findings reported by Sajjadi et al.[35](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR35 "Sajjad, W. et al. A comprehensive review on the performance of diesel engine using biodiesel and nano-additives. Energy Rep. 6, 3856‚Äì3886. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyr.2020.10.057

 (2020)."), where oxygen-rich nano additives enhanced combustion efficiency while slightly elevating NO‚Çì due to higher localized temperatures.

Overall, while our results generally align with existing literature, variations in fuel formulation, test engine specifications, and nanoparticle properties contribute to differences in outcomes. These comparisons reinforce the importance of standardized testing protocols and nanoparticle characterization to enable more meaningful cross-study evaluations. While previous research has investigated the influence of individual nanoparticles on biodiesel performance and emissions, the present study advances the field by offering a comparative evaluation of three different nano-additives (TiO2, CeO2, and ZnO) blended with waste cooking oil biodiesel. This comparative approach not only identifies TiO2 as the most effective additive for enhancing combustion efficiency and reducing emissions but also provides deeper insights into the underlying chemical mechanisms that govern these improvements. By combining renewable waste-derived fuel with nano-scale catalytic enhancement, this work contributes novel evidence toward developing cleaner, more efficient, and practically viable biodiesel formulations for diesel engine applications.

Conclusion

The results of the present research anchor the viability of waste cooking oil-based biodiesel mixed with nano additive as a renewable and environmentally friendly fuel compared to traditional diesel fuel.

Experimental investigation revealed that B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) fuel had enhanced performance and emission properties under single-cylinder CI engine operating at peak load condition at 1500 rpm. Addition of nano additives like Cerium, Zinc, and Titanium oxide led to improvement in combustion efficiency and extreme reduction in harmful emissions compared to premium diesel. B20 + TiO2 exhibited the most encouraging outcome, which emphasizes the significant role played by Titanium oxide in fuel optimization. Nevertheless, such benefits notwithstanding, the research also reflects specific limitations worthy of further study. The B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) blend has shown slight brake thermal efficiency (BTE) and brake specific energy consumption (BSEC) reduction of 2.53% and 3.80%, respectively, against the premium diesel.
Also, the slight reduction in pressure in the cylinder and in the heat release rate (HRR) were seen at larger crank angles at a rate of 1.76% and 7.59%, respectively. Such fluctuation may be adjusted due to the enhanced atomization and postponed ignition process which result in maintaining stability during combustion. Though these are small variations in the performance parameters, optimization of fuel injection strategy and combustion parameters can offset such losses and provide better efficiency. Long-term engine durability testing will also be essential to determine probable effects of nano additives on engine components with respect to wear and deposit formation. For the emissions, B20 + TiO2 showed a reduction of 17.41% in unburned hydrocarbons (UBHC), a reduction of 36.36% in carbon monoxide (CO) emission, and a reduction of 16.24% in smoke emission when compared to diesel. However, the sole limitation noted was the increase in nitrogen oxide (NO‚Çì) emissions by 8.58%, a typical defect noted with the use of biodiesel owing to the existence of greater oxygen content and enhanced combustion properties.
While NO‚Çì formation is more directly associated with high combustion temperatures, methods like exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) or catalytic after-treatment systems can be investigated to avoid these emissions without compromising the fuel‚Äôs overall advantages. There also must be further research that confirms the long-term dispersion behaviour and stability of nano additives when they are present in biodiesel so that for sustained performance, it can disperse in an even fuel matrix. Application of nano additives such as TiO2 with waste cooking oil biodiesel at 25 ppm is one potential move towards cleaner and more sustainable fuels. This abolishes the use of fossil fuels and supports the environment through emissions reduction. Still, there are issues involving NO‚Çì emissions, stability of fuel, and long-term consequences on the engine parts which have to be eliminated in favour of making the blends more comfortable to produce for commercial and large-scale industrial utilization.
The slight increase in NOx emissions with B20 + TiO2 is primarily due to higher combustion temperatures resulting from better oxygen availability and combustion efficiency. However, TiO2‚Äôs oxygen buffering property helps minimize localized hot-spots, slightly mitigating NOx compared to CeO2 and ZnO2 blends. Potential challenges like nano additive agglomeration, injector wear, and long-term engine deposit formation are recognized and merit future investigation. Additionally, the use of a single engine type, variability in waste cooking oil quality, and laboratory-scale conditions limit the broader generalizability of findings.
Additional research into the optimization of nano additive levels, and on-board engine testing under different operating regimes, will be necessary in proving the viability and scalability of this fuel blend as an energy source.

New Haven plant now the East Coast‚Äôs largest producer of biofuels

by P.R. Lockhart and John Moritz, CT Mirror 
December 1, 2025

 New Haven plant now the East Coast‚Äôs largest producer of biofuels by P.R. Lockhart and John Moritz, CT Mirror December 1, 2025 Inside a green metal-clad building in the Port of New Haven, a kind of modern day alchemy is at work, turning used cooking oil into fuel capable of powering trucks and heating homes. Within a maze of tightly stacked tanks, pipes and collection units, workers take the grease ‚Äî or other available waste products such as animal fats, tallow and vegetable oils ‚Äî and add an alcohol catalyst to trigger a chemical reaction that produces biodiesel, which is marketed as a more climate friendly alternative to traditional fossil fuels. A series of rapid expansions in recent years has made the plant, home of American GreenFuels, the largest producer of biodiesel on the East Coast. Originally opened in 2011 as Greenleaf Biofuels, the plant was later purchased by the American division of Swiss commodities trader Kolmar Group and renamed American GreenFuels. Since 2016, its output has quadrupled, from 15 million gallons to nearly 60 million gallons a year. The most recent expansion, completed this summer, added a second story to the production floor. "It often smells like french fries, as you might expect," said Paul Teta, the vice president and general counsel for Kolmar Americas, which is based in Shelton. The company's growth has been spurred, in part, by government subsidies and laws requiring fuel dealers to blend home heating oil with biodiesel in an effort to reduce carbon emissions. Teta declined to say how much the company has invested in its New Haven plant, other than to say it was in the "many millions of dollars." According to Kolmar, the biodiesel made at its New Haven facility produces 86% less greenhouse gas emissions, on average, compared with ultralow-sulfur heating oil. The emissions reductions are even more substantial when the fuel is sold and burned in Connecticut, removing the need to transport it long distances on trucks. Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market Forecast and Outlook 2025 to 2035

Why Does Renewable Fuel Demand Drive UCO Market Expansion?

The used cooking oil market grows by enabling biodiesel producers, renewable fuel manufacturers, and oleochemical processors to access sustainable feedstock alternatives that support production mandates while meeting environmental demand for waste-derived raw materials.

Industrial operations face mounting requirements to implement renewable feedstock sourcing strategies with verified sustainability credentials, with UCO feedstock typically providing superior carbon intensity scores and regulatory compliance essential for competitive operations in biofuel production and green chemistry sectors.

The renewable energy industry's need for diverse feedstock portfolios and consistent supply reliability creates demand for various UCO grades that can provide optimal conversion efficiency, maintain stable quality parameters across different collection sources, and ensure regulatory compliance without compromising process economics or sustainability standards.

Government initiatives promoting circular economy principles and renewable fuel deployment drive adoption in biodiesel refineries, sustainable aviation fuel facilities, and oleochemical manufacturing operations, where UCO utilization has a direct impact on carbon footprint reduction and sustainability performance outcomes.

The biofuel industry's growing focus on waste-based feedstock prioritization and low-carbon fuel production further expands market opportunities, with lifecycle analysis demonstrating measurable greenhouse gas reduction benefits through UCO-based biodiesel utilization, renewable identification number generation, and carbon credit qualification programs.

Collection infrastructure limitations affecting feedstock availability and technical requirements for contamination removal and moisture management may limit accessibility among smaller biodiesel producers and developing regions with underdeveloped waste oil recovery systems and feedstock aggregation infrastructure.

The biodiesel production segment's market leadership stems from its essential feedstock requirements, with UCO capable of meeting diverse fuel specification demands while maintaining high conversion yields and operational reliability across all refining environments.

The oleochemicals segment maintains a substantial 12.3% market share, serving manufacturers who require sustainable raw materials for soap production, surfactant formulation, and specialty chemical applications. Other significant application segments include animal feed production utilizing processed UCO as energy-dense feed ingredients, and miscellaneous industrial applications serving specialized requirements. What are the Drivers, Restraints, and Key Trends of the Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market?

The market is driven by three concrete demand factors tied to sustainability mandates and circular economy adoption. First, increasing renewable fuel mandates globally create growing demand for waste-based feedstock alternatives, with biodiesel blending requirements expanding by 5-8% annually in major economies requiring comprehensive UCO supply infrastructure. Second, government incentives promoting waste valorization and circular economy principles drive increased collection participation rates, with many countries implementing extended producer responsibility frameworks and waste diversion targets for organic waste streams by 2030\. Third, technological advancements in feedstock pre-treatment and conversion processes enable more effective UCO utilization that reduces processing costs while improving biodiesel yield and quality specifications across diverse refining configurations.

Market restraints include inconsistent collection infrastructure across different regions that can limit feedstock availability and supply reliability, particularly in developing markets where commercial collection services remain underdeveloped. Quality variability and contamination concerns pose another significant challenge, as UCO feedstock requires extensive testing and pre-treatment to meet biodiesel specifications, potentially causing increased processing costs and yield losses. Competition from alternative waste feedstocks including animal fats and vegetable oil processing residues creates additional market dynamics affecting pricing, demanding strategic feedstock sourcing and blending optimization programs.

Key trends indicate accelerated collection infrastructure development in Asia Pacific markets, particularly India and China, where rapid urbanization and food service expansion drive substantial UCO generation growth. Technology integration trends toward blockchain-based traceability systems with digital collection documentation, automated quality testing protocols, and integrated supply chain management platforms enable transparent feedstock verification approaches that optimize sustainability certification and regulatory compliance capabilities. However, the market thesis could face disruption if significant advances in synthetic biology enable cost-competitive production of drop-in biofuels from alternative feedstocks or major policy changes reduce renewable fuel mandates across key biodiesel markets.

Global Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market - Stakeholder Contribution Framework

Used cooking oil represents a critical renewable feedstock that enables biodiesel producers, oleochemical manufacturers, and renewable fuel refineries to achieve sustainability targets and regulatory compliance without virgin feedstock dependency, typically providing 80-85% greenhouse gas reduction compared to fossil diesel while enabling waste stream monetization.

With the market projected to grow from USD 8.56 billion in 2025 to USD 17.18 billion by 2035 at a 7.2% CAGR, this feedstock offers compelling advantages - proven carbon intensity benefits, established conversion technologies, and circular economy alignment - making it essential for biodiesel production (major application), sustainable aviation fuel development (emerging segment), and diverse renewable energy applications seeking waste-based feedstock solutions. Scaling collection infrastructure and supply reliability requires coordinated action across waste management policy, sustainability standards, collection service providers, biodiesel producers, and food service operators.

 How Governments Could Spur Local Collection and Utilization?

Collection Infrastructure Programs: Include UCO recovery systems in municipal waste management initiatives, providing targeted funding for commercial collection equipment in urban centers and supporting collection service providers through route development grants and infrastructure assistance.
Regulatory Framework & Incentives: Implement mandatory UCO collection requirements for commercial food service, provide tax incentives for collection service investments, and establish favorable renewable fuel credit frameworks that encourage domestic utilization over export alternatives.
Circular Economy Support: Create streamlined waste oil transfer permits across collection and processing facilities, establish clear feedstock classification standards for UCO materials, and develop cross-border trade facilitation protocols that enable efficient feedstock movement.
Food Service Education Programs: Fund awareness campaigns for restaurant operators, commercial kitchen managers, and hospitality professionals. Invest in training initiatives that bridge proper disposal practices with collection service engagement and sustainability reporting capabilities.

How Industry Bodies Could Support Market Development?

Quality Standards & Certification: Define standardized feedstock specifications for UCO across biodiesel and oleochemical applications, establish universal testing protocols for contaminant levels, and create certification programs for collection quality that processors can specify.
Best Practices & Guidelines: Lead industry initiatives that demonstrate proper UCO management advantages, emphasizing proven environmental benefits, revenue generation opportunities, and regulatory compliance advantages compared to drain disposal practices.
Supply Chain Integration Standards: Develop traceability protocols for feedstock documentation, comprehensive chain-of-custody requirements, and sustainability certification platforms, ensuring verification credibility across different collection environments and processing requirements.

 How Collection Companies and Processors Could Strengthen the Ecosystem?

Collection Infrastructure Development: Develop efficient collection route systems with optimized scheduling, reliable service delivery, and customer-friendly container solutions that enhance participation economics while reducing operational costs.
Quality Management Systems: Provide comprehensive feedstock testing that integrates contamination analysis, moisture content verification, free fatty acid measurement, and sustainability documentation, enabling processors to maximize conversion efficiency and regulatory credit generation.
Partnership Networks: Offer flexible service arrangements for food service operators and hospitality chains, including scheduled collection options, reporting services, and revenue-sharing programs that keep UCO recovery aligned with operational requirements and sustainability goals.

Multiple people charged for interstate transportation of stolen cooking oil to be converted to biodiesel

 in Washington D.C.")

Published:

December 31, 2025

By Ashley

FacebookTwitterWhatsAppCopy URL

Multiple individuals were charged in connection with a scheme to steal cooking oil from restaurants throughout the South and the Midwest for resale as biodiesel fuel, officials say.

On December 9, 2025, a federal grand jury in Des Moines returned a nine-count indictment charging several people with racketeering conspiracy, conspiracy to commit the offense of interstate transportation of stolen property, and money laundering, according to the U.S. Attorney‚Äôs Office for the Southern District of Iowa.

Officials say that the defendants used trucks to steal used cooking oil from collection tanks located at restaurants throughout Iowa, Tennessee, Minnesota, Indiana, Ohio, Alabama, Illinois, Nebraska, Missouri, and Kentucky.

The stolen cooking oil was then transported to warehouses in Nevada and Ankeny, Iowa; Lewisburg, Tennessee; Dora, Alabama; and Tipp City, Ohio.

The used cooking oil was refined into biodiesel fuel and re-sold, officials said, and the proceeds from the scheme were laundered.

See below for more information on the charged individuals:

Tianzhu Chen, 33, of Flushing, New York, is charged with racketeering conspiracy, conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate, two counts of interstate transportation of stolen property, and two counts of money laundering.
Jingliu Chen, 55, of Flushing, New York, is charged with conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate.
Yong Chen, 32, of Brooklyn, New York, is charged with racketeering conspiracy, conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate, and two counts of interstate transportation of stolen property.
Xian Quan Guo, 48, of Des Moines, Iowa, is charged with racketeering conspiracy and conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate.
Jianfa Huang, 40, of Des Moines, Iowa, is charged with racketeering conspiracy, conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate, and interstate transportation of stolen property.
Fukang Wang, 37, of Staten Island, New York, is charged with racketeering conspiracy and conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate.
Futao Wang, 36, of Des Moines, Iowa, is charged with racketeering conspiracy, conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate, and interstate transportation of stolen property.
Jie Wang, 30, of Dayton, Ohio, is charged with racketeering conspiracy and conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate.
Xiangjing Wang, 34, of Des Moines, Iowa, is charged with racketeering conspiracy, conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate, and two counts of interstate transportation of stolen property.
Danrong Zhang, 38, of Flushing, New York, is charged with conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate and money laundering.
Changxu Zou, 41, of Tulia, Texas, is charged with conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate.
Changyu Zou, 38, of Edmond, Oklahoma, is charged with racketeering conspiracy and conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate.
Wenrong Zou, 32, of Edmond, Oklahoma, is charged with conspiracy to transport stolen property interstate

Agencies assisting with this investigation include the Central Iowa Gang Task Force of the FBI Des Moines Resident Agency of the Omaha Field Office, the Polk County Sheriff‚Äôs Office, Story County Sheriff‚Äôs Office, Des Moines Police Department, West Des Moines Police Department, Iowa Department of Public Safety, Iowa Department of Transportation, Gahanna, Ohio Police Department, Cullman, Alabama Police Department, Springfield, Illinois, Police Department, 18th Judicial District Drug Task Force in Tennessee, FBI Dayton Resident Agency of the Cincinnati Field Office, FBI Lexington Resident Agency of the Springfield Field Office, FBI Oklahoma City Field Office, FBI New York City Field Office, FBI Birmingham Field Office, FBI Amarillo Resident Agency of the Dallas Field Office, FBI Language Services, and the Environmental Protection Agency.

Used Cooking Oil Market

The Global Used Cooking Oil Market was valued at approximately USD 7.50 Billion in 2023 and is projected to expand to about USD 11.35 Billion by 2030, registering a CAGR of around 6.1% during the forecast period (2024‚Äê2030). 

Market Overview 

Used Cooking Oil -collected from households, commercial kitchens, restaurants, and food processing units-is a key feedstock for several downstream applications, especially biodiesel production, oleochemicals, animal feed, and specialty industrial products. Recycling Used Cooking Oil not only addresses environmental waste concerns but also contributes to the global transition toward cleaner energy sources. Governments across major regions are implementing policies and incentives to promote collection, recycling, and sustainable utilisation of used cooking oils, thereby boosting industry growth.

Market Key Growth Drivers 

1\. Rapid Expansion of Biodiesel & Renewable Fuels 
Biodiesel remains the largest application segment for Used Cooking Oil due to its cost efficiency, lower carbon emissions, and alignment with renewable energy goals. Increasing renewable fuel mandates and biofuel blending targets globally are driving demand for Used Cooking Oil as a critical biodiesel feedstock. 

2\. Environmental Regulations & Government Support 
Countries in Europe, North America, and Asia are enforcing stringent waste management regulations and incentives to promote Used Cooking Oil collection and recycling, supporting sustainability targets and circular economy goals. 

3\. Growth in Food Service & HoReCa Sector 
The rapid rise of restaurants, hotels, and cloud kitchens is generating larger volumes of Used Cooking Oil, increasing availability for downstream processing and biodiesel production. 

4\. Technological Advancements in Processing 
Improved filtration, refining, and purification technologies enhance Used Cooking Oil quality for high‚Äêvalue applications, reducing barriers to entry and expanding market potential. 

Market Challenges 

1\. Quality and Collection Issues 
Inconsistent quality of used cooking oil and fragmented collection systems pose significant challenges, requiring additional processing costs and infrastructure development. 

2\. Logistical & Supply Chain Constraints 
Efficient collection and transportation of Used Cooking Oil involve complex logistics, strict regulations, and specialized equipment, which can inhibit market entry for smaller players. 

3\. Competitive Feedstock Landscape 
As the demand for alternative renewable feedstocks increases, competition for Used Cooking Oil drives pricing pressures, particularly in biodiesel and oleochemical sectors. 

Recent Developments 

Regulatory Shifts: Indonesia imposed new export regulations for Used Cooking Oil and palm oil residues to prioritise domestic use and biodiesel blending mandates. 

Industry Expansion: Several companies, including M11 Industries in India, have launched new biodiesel processing facilities with significant capacity increases. 

Sustainability Initiatives: Leading market players are enhancing Used Cooking Oil collection networks and investing in advanced refining technologies to increase efficiency and product quality.

Emerging Opportunities 

1\. Household & Decentralised Collection Programs 
Untapped potential remains in household Used Cooking Oil collection, with future growth expected from community and municipality‚Äêled recycling initiatives. 

2\. Aviation & Sustainable Fuels 
Growing interest in Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF) and advanced biofuels represent a high‚Äêgrowth segment for Used Cooking Oil processing applications. 

3\. Circular Economy Solutions 
Corporate and government partnerships are creating innovative business models that integrate Used Cooking Oil recycling into broader waste management and energy strategies.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) 

1\. What is the global used cooking oil market size? 
The global Used Cooking Oil market was valued at approximately USD 7.50 Billion in 2023 and is expected to reach around USD 11.35 Billion by 2030. 

2\. What are the primary applications of Used Cooking Oil? 
Key applications include biodiesel production, oleochemicals, animal feed, and industrial uses, with biodiesel being the largest segment. 

3\. What regions dominate the Used Cooking Oil market? 
North America and Europe hold substantial market shares, supported by strong biodiesel industries and recycling infrastructure. 

4\. What are the main market drivers? 
Growing renewable energy mandates, regulatory support, sustainable waste management, and increased food service oil consumption drive market growth. 

5\. What challenges does the industry face? 
Key challenges include inconsistent quality of Used Cooking Oil, logistic and collection inefficiencies, and competitive feedstock pricing dynamics.

‚úÖ October 2025: Federal incentives expanded for UCO-to-biodiesel conversion projects, boosting collection from restaurants by 15% in key states like California. Darling Ingredients announced a new processing facility in Texas to handle increased volumes. 

Recent Key Developments of Japan: 

‚úÖ December 2025: Local authorities funded demonstration projects converting UCO to clean fuel, enhancing logistical networks and market CAGR projection to 5.43% through 2033. 

‚úÖ November 2025: Retail sales grew 2.8% year-over-year, per official data, amplifying UCO generation from ready-meal counters and hot food sections nationwide. 

‚úÖ October 2025: Government subsidies for biodiesel from UCO increased, aligning with national climate goals and supporting local converters. Retail expansion in supermarkets raised recoverable oil volumes.

Abstract

Biofuels produced from food system wastes offer a promising way to substitute fossil fuels in food transportation and decarbonize both food and transportation sectors. Country-specific wastes inventories remain to be combined with biofuel conversion pathways to unravel the decarbonization potentials in global food transportation. Herein, we design a food system internal loop and quantify multi-path biofuel production from used cooking oil and crop residues across 130 countries to evaluate effects on fossil fuel substitution and carbon dioxide emission reductions. Road transportation dominates fossil fuel demands (80.7%) and emissions (79.5%) in food transportation. China and the United States excel in production of biofuels from two sources. Maximum production of both types of biofuels reaches 0.41 and 38.77 exajoules, respectively. Utilizing all available used cooking oil and less than 20% of crop residues could completely satisfy food transportation fuel demands in most countries while mitigating emissions by 174.9 million tons (around 70%).

 Introduction

The food system, as a key component of human economic activity, is responsible for approximately one-third of global anthropogenic greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions1."). Food transportation bridges food and transportation systems. A study based on ‚Äúfood miles‚Äù concept revealed that, when considering the entire food supply chain, emissions from food transportation account for \~19% of global food system emissions2."). This underscores the critical need for strategies aimed at mitigating emissions associated with food transportation, contributing co-benefits in decarbonizing both food system and transportation system.

With global population growth and an increasing demand for food, the amount of wastes generated by food system has risen sharply. Proper management of food system wastes has thus become a crucial aspect of controlling or mitigating emissions within food system3."),4."),5."),6."),7."). The conversion of food system wastes into biofuels for transportation has already seen widespread application. Among food system wastes, used cooking oil (UCO) and crop residues (CRs) demonstrate advantages in collection and treatment efficiency, exhibiting more homogeneous compositions compared with other wastes such as kitchen waste. Additionally, the technologies for their conversion into biofuels are more mature, establishing them as primary feedstocks for biofuel production8."),9."),10."),11."). Biodiesel is the most common form of biofuels, primarily used in road, railway & inland waterway, and marine transportation12."),13 420‚Äì424 (PEEIC, 2018)."),14.").

Established pathways for converting UCO include esterification-hydrogenation and Hydroprocessed Esters and Fatty Acids (HEFA) processes following hydrolysis15."),16."). Esterification-hydrogenation yields high-quality biodiesel suitable for road, rail, and inland waterway transport by effectively converting UCO fatty acids. HEFA technology, involving high-pressure hydrogenation, transforms UCO lipids into drop-in sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), currently the dominant bio-aviation pathway, achieving higher energy density and combustion performance17."),18 265‚Äì286 (Springer Nature, Singapore, 2023)."),19."),20."). CRs can be converted via fast pyrolysis or gasification-Fischer-Tropsch synthesis21."),22."). Fast pyrolysis rapidly decomposes solid biomass into liquid bio-oil, while Fischer-Tropsch synthesis produces premium liquid fuels from syngas without requiring specific feedstock chemical structures, making it suitable for producing Fischer-Tropsch aviation fuel from lignocellulosic materials like CRs17."),18 265‚Äì286 (Springer Nature, Singapore, 2023)."),19."),20."). Life cycle assessment (LCA) is widely employed to compare different fuel technologies, with numerous studies demonstrating that biofuels, when replacing fossil fuels, result in significant emission reduction23 people‚Äôs republic of China. Appl. Energy 86, S197‚ÄìS208 (2009)."),24."),25."). Regarding the collection and energy potential of CRs and UCO, a large number of research has estimated the amount of CRs available in different regions based on crop yields and residue indices26."),27."),28."),29."). When estimating the energy potential of CRs, it is crucial to account for competing uses beyond biofuel production30."),31."). Contextualized in the diverse ways of CRs utilization, and the influence of climate and dietary habits on their spatial distribution, extant research has conducted analysis of CRs‚Äô competing uses targeting typical countries or regions32."),33."),34."). Studies on UCO recycling predominantly address collection and transportation strategies at the consumption end35."),36."). Unlike CRs, which have multiple competing uses, the main energy utilization pathway for UCO is biodiesel production34."),35."),36."),37."). Various conversion technologies have been examined to explore UCO‚Äôs potential for biofuel production38."),39."),40."),41.").

Building on studies of food system wastes‚Äô energy potentials, some research has also analyzed the emission reduction benefits of biofuel production from food system wastes in specific regions. Typical studies cover estimates of the emission reduction potential of biodiesel produced from CRs in Europe for use in marine transportation42."), assessment of the bioenergy potential and emission reduction contributed by CRs utilization in China43."), analysis of the environmental impacts of converting UCO to biodiesel in China44."), and evaluation of the emission reduction effect of biodiesel produced from UCO in Iran under specific UCO recycling strategies45."). These studies further demonstrate the potential of utilizing wastes-derived biofuels for controlling transportation emissions in practical applications.

While converting food system wastes to biofuels has demonstrated effectiveness in fossil fuel substitution and emission reduction, critical knowledge gaps remain. First, from a food system perspective, the energy and environmental benefits feedback achievable by repurposing such biofuels specifically for food transportation remains unclear. Second, existing research lacks an integrated analytical framework that concurrently addresses global variations in food system wastes availability and disparate food transportation fuel demands across countries. Consequently, the extent to which domestically produced biofuels can offset heterogeneous transportation fossil fuel demands remains unknown, hindering the characterization of individual countries‚Äô contributions to decarbonizing global food and transportation systems.

To address these gaps, this study establishes an internal recycling loop within the food system where food system waste streams are repurposed for food transportation. It aims to quantify national-level biofuel production potentials from such wastes and evaluate the corresponding contribution in decarbonizing food system transportation by substituting fossil fuels. The internal recycling loop within food system is illustrated in Fig. 1, the food system spans five sequential stages: agricultural production, food transportation and trade, processing and transformation, retail and provisioning, and food consumption. UCO and CRs generated from these stages are collected and processed into biofuels. These biofuels then substitute fossil fuels across various transportation modes (road, railway & inland waterway, marine, aviation), providing energy for food transportation while reducing emissions within the food system. Though biofuel utilization may extend beyond food-related transportation in practice, emerging carbon trading mechanisms and global carbon market developments enable the reallocation of environmental benefits to food systems through carbon quota allocations or fiscal incentives46."),47."). This approach creates synergistic feedback between emission reductions in the transportation sector and sustainability improvements in food production chains.

The icons used are sourced from .

Full size image

From the food system internal loop perspective, targeting 130 countries in the world, the availability and biofuel production potentials of CRs and UCO in various countries are accounted, combined with examining country-specific fossil fuel demands of food transportation adopting multiregional input-output model (MRIO). On this basis, four scenarios are designed to analyze the biofuel production and emission reduction contributions under varying food system wastes utilization levels (scenario of sole UCO utilization, scenario of sole CRs utilization, scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization, and scenario of maximum biofuel production potential). The life cycle analysis and GREET (greenhouse gases, regulated emissions, and energy use in transportation) model are combined to compare the well-to-wheel/haul/wake (WTW/WTH/WTWa) emissions from typical biofuels and fossil fuels under the four scenarios, including emissions from the production phase (well-to-pump, WTP) and the operation phase (pump-to-wheel/haul/wake, PTW/PTH/PTWa). The findings are expected to provide references for informing global energy utilization strategies of food system wastes, and sustainability of food transportation.

Results

 Fossil fuel demand of global food transportation

Analysis of this study reveals that the aggregate food transportation fossil fuel demand across 130 countries amounts to around 3.0 EJ (1 EJ = 1018 J), constituting 3.3% of total transportation fossil fuel demand. Figure 2 illustrates the distribution of food transportation fossil fuel demands across various transportation modes. As one of the world‚Äôs preeminent food producers and consumers, China exhibits substantially higher food transportation fossil fuel demand compared with other countries. Similarly, other major food-producing countries, including India, Brazil, the United States, and Russia, demonstrate elevated demand, while the African and Middle Eastern countries show comparatively lower demand. Among four transportation modes, road transportation dominates the fossil fuel demand, accounting for \~80.6% of total demand across 130 countries. Aviation and marine transport follow with 8.4% and 7.4% respectively. Railway & inland waterway transportation exhibits significantly lower fossil fuel dependence (3.6% combined), primarily due to the higher electrification levels of railway. Regionally, railway & inland waterway fuel demands are concentrated in China, Latin America, and the Middle East, with China and Russia recording elevated shares of 8.86% and 6.25% respectively. Notably, archipelagic and coastal countries like the Philippines, Brunei, and Indonesia demonstrate exceptional marine fossil fuel intensity, with marine transportation constituting over 20% of their national fossil fuel consumption.

The color depth presents the amount of fossil fuel demand, and the pie chart presents the fuel demand shares across transportation modes in the top 30 countries with emissions.

Biofuel production from food system wastes

This study suggests that the theoretically maximum biofuel production from UCO across 130 countries reaches 0.41 EJ (1.03%), while CRs-derived biofuels exhibit an overwhelmingly higher potential of 38.77 EJ (98.97%). This disparity arises because CRs possess inherent advantages in sheer amount, being inevitable agricultural byproducts with broad geographical distribution. While UCO, despite its higher conversion efficiency, is constrained by limited waste oil availability and immature collection infrastructure. These limitations collectively restrict UCO‚Äôs total biofuel production potential far below that of CRs. Figure 3 delineates the biofuel production from UCO and CRs across countries, revealing that those with higher food production and consumption demonstrate correspondingly greater potentials. Regionally, for UCO-derived biofuel production, China (106.8 PJ, 1 PJ = 1015 J) and the United States (100.0 PJ) collectively contribute 51.0% of the global total, driven by their extensive food service industries and consumption patterns. Major oilseed-producing countries, including Indonesia (32.6 PJ), Malaysia (29.5 PJ), and India (15.8 PJ), form the secondary tier, contributing 19.2% of the global total and correlating with their expanding vegetable oil utilization in food processing sectors. For CRs-derived biofuel production, major agricultural countries demonstrate overwhelming advantages: China (10.7 EJ), the United States (8.2 EJ), India (7.6 EJ), and Brazil (6.4 EJ) collectively account for 55.2% of the total, supported by vast croplands and high-intensity farming systems. Other leading grain producers such as Russia and Argentina follow, with CRs-derived biofuel production surpassing 2 EJ.

The biofuel production from UCO and CRs varies significantly depending on their utilization rate (especially competing uses for CRs) and energy conversion efficiency. UCO demonstrates superior energy conversion efficiency compared with CRs (Table S5 in Supplementary Information), yielding higher biofuel production per unit of wastes (PJ). Figure 4 presents a comparative result between fossil fuel demand and biofuel production from UCO and CRs across 11 regions (divided according to World Oil Outlook from OPEC[48](/articles/s43247-025-02891-0ref-CR48 "Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries. World Oil Outlook 2045. 
 https://www.opec.org/assets/assetdb/woo-2022.pdf

 (2022)."), with clustering of countries by economic parity and geographic proximity) under four scenarios. Table S8 provides detailed country-specific data regarding the fossil fuel demand that could be satisfied by UCO and CRs-derived biofuels. In the scenario of sole UCO utilization, significant biofuel production is seen in Asia, OECD Americas, and Europe. In the scenario of sole CRs utilization, despite a 7% utilization limit, CRs show broader potential, with over a third of 130 countries fully covering their food transportation fossil fuel demand. This performance confirms CRs‚Äô persistently superior biofuel production capacity relative to UCO, attributable to their fundamental advantage in sheer production amount. The scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization outperforms sole-feedstock scenarios, meeting most food transportation fossil fuel demand except in the Middle East and Russia. In the scenario of maximum biofuel production potential, the biofuel production exceeds food transportation fossil fuel demand in most regions, with India and Latin America capable of meeting their entire transportation sector‚Äôs fossil fuel demand (Fig. S2).

Emission reductions in food transportation through food system wastes-derived biofuels

Total emissions from the production and use of fossil fuels in food transportation across 130 countries are 256.6 million metric tonnes (Mt) CO2. Figure 5 shows emission distributions across four transportation modes in 11 regions. Road transportation dominates the total emissions, contributing 204.7 Mt CO‚ÇÇ (80.7% of emissions across four modes), followed by aviation and marine transportation with tied contributions (19.8 Mt CO‚ÇÇ, 7.8%). Railway & inland waterway transportation exhibits the lowest emissions at 9.2 Mt CO‚ÇÇ, accounting for only 3.7%. Regionally, China exhibits the highest emissions across all modes except marine transportation, with road transportation (48.5 Mt CO‚ÇÇ, 23.7% of global road transportation emissions) and railway & inland waterway transportation (4.9 Mt CO‚ÇÇ, 53.5% of global railway & inland waterway transportation emissions) being particularly significant. Other Asian regions, the Middle East, and Latin America collectively account for around half of marine transportation emissions, each exceeding 25 Mt CO‚ÇÇ. In aviation transportation, OECD European countries (31.95 Mt CO‚ÇÇ, 16.12% of global aviation transportation emissions) emerge as major contributors alongside China.

Each country exhibits distinct emission reduction profiles in food transportation by utilizing food system wastes-derived biofuels. Figure 6a‚Äìd illustrates country-specific emission reductions across scenarios, with details for 130 countries presented in Table S9. The scenario of sole UCO utilization achieves 28.9 Mt CO‚ÇÇ reductions (11.4% of food transportation emissions), with emission reduction proportions in high UCO producers like Malaysia and Indonesia being as high as over 95%, while other countries mostly achieve reductions in the 0‚àí20% range in this scenario. The scenario of sole CRs utilization achieves 119.1 Mt CO‚ÇÇ reductions (47.0%), with China, India, Brazil, and the US contributing above half of total reductions. Approximately half of the analyzed countries attain over 50% reductions in their national emissions. The scenario of UCO and CRs co-utilization achieves 135.0 Mt CO‚ÇÇ reductions (53.2%), nearly half of the analyzed countries could achieve complete offset of food transportation fossil fuel demand through food system wastes-derived biofuels, achieving 70%‚àí83% emission reductions. Under the scenario of maximum biofuel production potential, reductions reach 174.9 Mt CO‚ÇÇ (69.0%), with only 21 countries‚Äô food transportation fossil fuel demands being incompletely offset by food system wastes-derived biofuels, and nearly 80% of countries achieving an emission reduction proportion over 70%.

For four transportation modes, UCO-derived biofuels excel in reducing emissions from road, railway & inland waterway, while CRs-derived biofuels are more effective for marine and aviation (Table S7). As road transportation accounts for the highest fuel demand among the four modes, UCO-derived biofuels generally achieve greater overall emission reductions per unit when implementing biofuel substitution according to fuel demand shares for four modes. Under the scenario of maximum biofuel production potential, road transportation demonstrates global leadership in emission reduction, achieving 130.8 Mt CO‚ÇÇ reductions, constituting 76.9% of total food transportation emissions mitigation. Aviation and marine transportation follow with 17.3 Mt CO‚ÇÇ (9.9%) and 16.7 Mt CO‚ÇÇ (9.5%) reductions respectively, while railway & inland waterway transportation, constrained by existing electrification levels of railway, contribute marginally at 6.46 Mt CO‚ÇÇ (3.7%). Figure 6e shows emission reduction proportions across regions, transportation modes, and scenarios. All countries exhibit consistent, substantial road transportation reductions, particularly in the scenario of maximum biofuel production potential. Emission reductions in marine transportation are concentrated in coastal and island regions (e.g., the Philippines, Indonesia, and Malaysia), where marine transportation contributes up to 20% of national mitigation totals.  Uncertainty analysis

The calculations of fossil fuel demand, biofuel production, food transportation emissions, and emission reductions are rigorously examined using Monte Carlo analysis. The yield coefficients of CRs, along with the collection coefficients of CRs and UCO, determine the utilizable amount of food system wastes. The energy conversion coefficients of UCO and CRs, combined with their biofuel conversion coefficients, critically influence the amount of biofuel production. The fuel demand shares for four transportation modes directly govern fossil fuel demand across four transportation modes, which is essential for estimating fossil fuel emissions in food transportation. Additionally, WTW emission coefficients of biofuels and fossil fuels serve as pivotal parameters for quantifying emissions and emission reductions in food transportation. These key factors have therefore been incorporated into the uncertainty analysis of calculation outcomes.

The Monte Carlo method employs triangular distributions for parameter estimation, generating 10,000 independent simulations, with results aggregated using statistical indicators. As shown in Fig. 7, road transportation exhibits a broader uncertainty range in fossil fuel demand and emission calculations compared to other transportation modes, primarily due to its higher fuel demand share. The substantially greater utilizable amount of CRs relative to UCO amplifies uncertainty in the CRs derived-biofuel production potentials. Furthermore, the uncertainty ranges of emission reductions across the four scenarios increase incrementally with rising emission reduction levels, with the scenario of sole UCO utilization demonstrating a notably smaller uncertainty range than the other three scenarios.

Discussion

 Research remarks

Building upon the quantified global analysis of fossil fuel demand and emissions in food transportation across multiple countries, this study pioneers an internal recycling loop framework of food system. The study proposes converting food system wastes (UCO and CRs) into biofuels for food transportation, establishing a synchronized decarbonization pathway that simultaneously achieves waste valorization and dual-system (food-transportation) emission mitigation. TotalEnergies signs deal with Quatra for UCO feedstock

TotalEnergies and Quatra, the European market leader in the collection and recycling of used cooking oil, have signed a 15-year agreement beginning in 2026, for the supply of 60,000 tons a year of European used cooking oil to TotalEnergies‚Äô biorefineries. 
This deal contributes to secure the feedstock to produce biodiesel and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). 
Under the terms of the agreement, Quatra will collect used cooking oil directly from restaurants, restaurant chains and industry in France and the rest of Europe. The oil will then be delivered to Quatra sites for filtering before being shipped to TotalEnergies‚Äô biorefineries to produce road biofuels and SAF. 
TotalEnergies has converted its refineries at La M√®de in the south of France and Grandpuits near Paris into biorefineries. 
‚ÄúI am delighted with this strategic agreement with Quatra that contributes to our aim to secure the feedstock we need to produce biofuels in our biorefineries. The development of biofuels is one of our Company‚Äôs strategic goals. By directly reducing the carbon intensity of the energy products used by our customers, we are actively working with them as part of our net zero approach, together with society,‚Äù said Val√©rie Goff, senior vice-president, renewable fuels & chemicals at TotalEnergies. 
‚ÄúAt Quatra, we believe in long-term partnerships with leading industrial groups that combine logistics, environmental responsibility and financial viability. The deal between Quatra France and TotalEnergies is an excellent example of that. By supplying locally collected used cooking oil, we are contributing to a sustainable value chain. That allows us to focus on our core business, which is the efficient collection of used cooking oil across France, allowing TotalEnergies to turn that valuable resource into biofuel,‚Äù stated Pol Van Pollaert, Co-CEO, Quatra.

Viewpoint: US policy shift elevates domestic feedstocks

Market: Agriculture, Biofuels
02/01/26

US biofuel producers may increasingly turn to domestic feedstocks as restrictive biofuel and trade policies limit the use of foreign materials. 

The clean fuel production tax credit, known as 45Z, launched in 2025 to replace the $1/USG blender's tax credit. Under 45Z, foreign used cooking oil (UCO) became ineligible for credits, while foreign tallow retained access until tariffs introduced in the third quarter disrupted trade. Starting in 2026, 45Z will apply exclusively to biofuels made from North American feedstocks, effectively excluding all other foreign products. 

President Donald Trump's administration's push to curb imports aims to strengthen domestic feedstocks, particularly soybean oil, in US biofuel production. US soybean crush capacity has grown by 13pc since 2022, reaching 2.97bn bushels (bu)/yr *w*ith the addition of 10 new crush plants. Expanded capacity drove a record 227.6mn bu of soybean crush in October, with multiple monthly records set throughout 2025.

The US biodiesel sector continues to rely on soybean oil as its primary feedstock, with soybean oil accounting for roughly 70pc of the biodiesel feedstock mix in 2024\. Meanwhile, the renewable diesel (RD) and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) industries have increasingly targeted lower-carbon feedstocks to maximize credit value, resulting in soybean oil demand failing to meet the demand expectations of crushers.

Agricultural lobbyists have long blamed foreign feedstocks for displacing domestic crop-based materials and have consistently pushed for restrictions. Heavy imports since early 2023 sidelined domestic supply, with Chinese UCO flooding the market and Brazilian and Australian tallow following suit. This surge drove record-high UCO consumption in July 2024, while tallow hit its own record in July 2025. 

Feedstock imports slowed in the second half of 2025 with new 45Z rules and import tariffs. Chinese UCO shipments in January-October 2025 fell by 65pc from a year earlier, while Brazilian tallow volumes plunged below 22mn lbs in the fourth quarter after 50pc tariffs were imposed in August, down from a record 154mn lbs in June. Australian tallow maintained strong flows until October despite 10pc tariffs, but volumes were expected to decline in late 2025 and beyond as 45Z restrictions take effect. 

In June, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) proposed record-high blending requirements for 2026 and 2027, alongside a measure to halve Renewable Identification Number (RIN) credit generation for fuels made abroad or from foreign feedstocks. This proposal sparked a rally in domestic feedstock prices, with most categories hitting yearly highs in July. 

Agricultural lobbyists and waste-based feedstock suppliers support these RIN changes, viewing them as a boost for domestic feedstock demand. But optimism for domestic feedstocks is tempered by uncertainty surrounding the 45Z credit and delays in biofuel mandates, which are expected to extend into 2026.

The Trump administration confirmed in December that mandates would not be finalized before year-end, leaving market players without guidance about final mandatory volumes and potential import RIN credit cuts. Also in December, the US Department of the Treasury submitted a new 45Z proposal to the White House, as market participants seek updated guidance on filing tax credit claims for 2025, though officials will likely permit the use of existing guidance for 2025 claims. 

This lack of clarity has triggered production cuts across multiple RD plants nationwide. Biofuel refiners such as Phillips 66 and Diamond Green Diesel have publicly announced rate reductions as renewable diesel margins dipped below 2024 levels. Some refiners continued tapping foreign feedstocks until December, avoiding some tariffs by claiming duty drawbacks and exporting the finished fuel abroad. Others remain cautious, as the half-RIN provision, if finalized, poses a significant risk to margins. 

Looking ahead, existing tariffs, new 45Z policies, record-high biofuel mandates, and the half-RIN provision are expected to support soybean oil demand in first-quarter 2026 as producers seek to maximize credits through domestic feedstock use. US soybean oil futures closed at 49.44¬¢/lb on 30 December, down by 14pc from their July peak of 57.54¬¢/lb, making soybean oil more attractive compared to waste-based feedstocks.

Agriculture groups claim that expanded crush capacity and record production will provide sufficient soybean oil to meet biofuel demand, reducing reliance on imported feedstocks. In addition, the 45Z credit premium for soybean oil is expected to rise in 2026 as regulators stop considering potential land-use impacts of crop-based fuels, narrowing the gap with credit values for waste-based feedstocks. Soybean oil is also positioned to gain a competitive advantage over canola oil, which receives a roughly 50pc lower credit value.

By Jamuna Gautam

---

News29/01/26 India to launch national SAF roadmap: ISMAIndia to launch national SAF roadmap: ISMAGoa, 29 January (Argus) ‚Äî India will launch a national sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) roadmap in the near term to provide clarity on guaranteed offtake and improve investor confidence, with a focus on the alcohol-to-jet pathway for SAF production, said Deepak Ballani, Director General of Indian Sugar and Bio-energy Manufacturers Association (ISMA). SAF in India will be a controlled product, with prices set by the government based on the feedstock costs, Ballani said on the sidelines of the India Energy Week in Goa. He was unable to comment on when the roadmap will be published. Ballani also said that India aims to produce 4bn litres of SAF for international flights. India has targeted to blend 1pc SAF into jet fuel for international flights by 2027, rising to 2pc by 2028 and 5pc by 2030\. Meanwhile, he noted that biodiesel production from used cooking oil (UCO) has not been viable because of feedstock aggregation issues, and current blending of biodiesel in diesel has been less than 1pc ‚Äî far short of the country's 5pc blending target for 2030\. Indian oil marketing companies are also working on blending ethanol into diesel, with trials in the preliminary stage, Ballani said. He added that India currently has the capacity to produce 32pc ethanol-blended gasoline and has reached its E20 target in 2025\. NewsBrazil central bank holds target rate at 15pc 28/01/26News28/01/26 Brazil central bank holds target rate at 15pcSao Paulo, 28 January (Argus) ‚Äî Brazil's central bank held its target rate unchanged at 15pc in its first meeting of 2026, citing an uncertain global environment due to US policies and their repercussions on global financial markets. The decision to hold the rate, announced on Wednesday, follows a string of similar decisions since June 2025, when the central bank wrapped up a series of seven increases that raised the rate from a cyclical low of 10.5pc in September 2024, the central bank said. Domestically, economic activity appears to be moderating while the labor market is showing signs of resilience. Headline and underlying inflation measures continue to soften, but still remain above the inflation target. Brazil's headline inflation decelerated to an annual 4.26pc in December. Still, inflation expectations, as calculated by the bank's Focus survey, remain above target, at 4pc and 3.8pc for 2026 and 2027\. The policy committee continues to monitor the impacts of the geopolitical context on Brazilian inflation, as well as how evolving fiscal policy impacts monetary policy and financial assets. Most financial market participants expected the central bank to hold at the first meeting of 2026 but project a 50 percentage point cut in March, bank BTG Pactual says. All rights reserved.NewsUS naphtha displaces Russian flows to Venezuela 28/01/26News28/01/26 US naphtha displaces Russian flows to VenezuelaNew York, 28 January (Argus) ‚Äî Naphtha shipments to Venezuela loading in January have come entirely from US Gulf coast suppliers, reversing the previous Russia-dominated trade for the diluent needed to transport Venezuelan crude after US intervention. Ports in Houston, Beaumont and Corpus Christi, Texas, have shipped between 970,000-1.22mn bl of naphtha to Venezuela so far this month, according to Kpler and Vortexa data, compared to 560,000-1.21mn bl for the last three months of 2025, when Chevron was the only oil major with a US government waiver to trade with Venezuela. Vitol has joined commodity trader Trafigura in this naphtha trade, after the US physically removed Venezuelan president Nicolas Maduro from power and cracked down on sanctioned vessel shipments to and from the country, cutting the primarily Russian flow of the diluent to Venezuela. Since 2023 Venezuela has been the importer for the majority of Caribbean-bound naphtha, and was typically the second-largest buyer of US Gulf coast naphtha, before the US government removed sanctions waivers in May 2025\. Buyers in the country primarily import naphtha on long range 1 (LR1) tankers, while the US Gulf coast spot market for refined product shipments is typically dominated by medium range (MR) tankers. Rising Venezuelan demand could spur additional LR1 demand from the US Gulf coast, which primarily trades as a backhaul for more liquid LR1 markets in deeper Pacific basin ports, especially for Mideast Gulf loadings. This could also affect the MR tanker market as other Caribbean naphtha buyers look to stock up ahead of further Venezuelan demand. Chevron sought an MR tanker for a US Gulf coast-Caribbean voyage on 27 January to load naphtha between 30 January and 1 February. A charterer later fixed at least one Caribbean-bound MR tanker at a $900,000 lumpsum on the same day, a 44pc jump in the voyage rate from the $625,000 lumpsum at the end of the trading day on 23 January. It is unclear if the second cargo was naphtha or another refined product. Naphtha spot participants unimpressed A swift rise in N+A naphtha prices on the US Gulf coast opened the arbitrage to the region, following the new supply agreement between the US and Venezuela. Differentials for heavy naphtha, the primary grade use as a Venezuelan diluent, shot up by more than 10¬¢/USG just before the first US naphtha shipment in early January. By mid-January, N+A naphtha differentials gave up all the gains. Selling interest for US Gulf coast naphtha diminished following the open arbitrage, potentially setting a precedent that sellers wanted to avoid in an already long market. A cargo of naphtha from Huelva, Spain, was booked for the US Gulf coast on 13 January with an estimated arrival of 3 February, shipping reports show. This supported the view that the naphtha arbitrage to the US Gulf coast was open. The Huelva cargo was reportedly suitable for blending to the Venezuelan diluent naphtha specification, but this was not confirmed. The Venezuelan diluent naphtha specification was roughly gauged as 70pc heavy naphtha and about 20-30pc lighter naphtha. Increased Venezuelan production in the longer run is not entirely bullish for US naphtha markets. Before Venezuelan production slowed during the regime of former president Hugo Chavez, Venezuela actively exported light naphtha from Jose and Las Salinas, primarily to the US Atlantic coast. Increased Venezuelan rates would also elevate naphtha production, which could diminish appetite for US naphtha imports and displace US naphtha market share globally. By Ross Griffith and Daphne Tan Send comments and request more information at feedback@argusmedia.com Copyright ¬© 2026\. Argus Media group . All rights reserved.NewsTrump threatens 100pc tariff on Canada 24/01/26News24/01/26 Trump threatens 100pc tariff on CanadaWashington, 24 January (Argus) ‚Äî President Donald Trump on Saturday threatened to impose a 100pc tariff on imports from Canada if Ottawa concludes a trade deal with Beijing. The trade deal, announced during Canadian prime minister Mark Carney's meeting with Chinese president Xi Jinping in Beijing on 16 January, involves China cutting combined tariffs on canola imports from Canada to 15pc by 1 March, and Canada allowing 49,000 electric vehicle imports a year from China at the most-favored-nation tariff of 6.1pc. Trump at the time said that "it's a good thing for (Carney) to sign a trade deal," adding that "if you can get a deal with China, you should do that." But Trump has changed his tune, writing on Saturday in a social media post, "If Governor (sic) Carney thinks he is going to make Canada a 'Drop Off Port' for China to send goods and products into the United States, he is sorely mistaken." The White House has not released any executive order backing Trump's Canada tariff threat, nor did it immediately explain which Canada-China trade deal he referenced. Trump's latest tariff follows an exchange of barbs that began at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, earlier this week. In a 20 January address to the forum, Carney ‚Äî without mentioning Trump by name ‚Äî issued a rebuke of Trump's aggressive global trade and military policy. Carney called on European countries to join Canada in finding alternatives to economic, trade and political alliances centered around Washington. Trump, addressing Davos a day later, shot back at Carney. "Canada lives because of the United States," Trump said. "Remember that, Mark, the next time you make your statements." Speaking during a visit to Qatar on Friday, Carney replied: "Canada doesn't live because of the United States. Canada thrives because we are Canadian." Trump is scheduled to visit Beijing in April for a meeting with Xi to discuss a possible US-China trade deal. US imports from Canada have been subject to a 35pc tariff since August, with separate duties on imported cars, auto parts, steel and aluminum. In practice, imports from Canada are taxed at the lowest rates among the top US trading partners, because the bulk of trade is exempted from tariffs under the terms of the US-Mexico-Canada free trade agreement. Energy commodities are also exempted from Trump's existing tariffs. Trump's ability to quickly levy tariffs on Canada and other trading partners is under review at the US Supreme Court, which is expected to issue a ruling soon. Trump's administration has not issued major tariff decisions in recent months, despite Trump's threats to do so. Trump earlier this month threatened to impose a 25pc tariff on US imports from countries doing business with Iran, but no decision has been made. Trump on 17 January threatened to impose a 10pc tariff on imports from the UK and seven EU members, which pushed back against his bid to annex Denmark's Greenland territory. Trump on 21 January withdrew that tariff threat after a slide in US stock and financial markets. By Haik Gugarats Send comments and request more information at feedback@argusmedia.com Copyright ¬© 2026\. Argus Media group . All rights reserved.
